reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minecraft and Alpha Centauri bumped into Skyrim and Spore leaving the over-budget rejects club. They all hooked up and had a weird four-parent-baby and named it Planet Explorers.

But enough about the game, lets talk about me. I have learned SO MUCH from playing Planet Explorers! I thought I needed friends and family and a life and a job and a future, but now I see those are all optional. All I really need is to mine more copper, find all the survivors, investigate the interference, learn more about the natives, help the earthlings and Martians get along peacefully, and always eat before I get a stomach ache because the ingredients for stomach medicine are so rare.

Planet Explorers gameplay is way too fun. I hate to admit it, but they may have finaly made a game that is better than real life. Some of the controls are quirky, and I'm sure that will bother a few at first. For example, RMB is for both moving the camera and stoweing your weapon/tool. So any time you are using your equipment, it gets put away the next time you move the camera. It is most annoying in combat but once you get used to it, it's fine.

The graphics in the game are way over-the-top. I have to run it on 'simple' just to get >10fps. I have an old computer though, so I doubt many people will share that experience. But, even on low graphics, the artwork is quite charming. It doesn't look -bad- until you get to the minimum setting.

The new content creation features are very well thought and add tremendous depth of freedom to the game. You can design almost anything- armors, weapons, tools, vehichles, buildings, etc. Getting your new designs into the game however is another story, as I have not yet been able to figure out how.

Problems- Combat gets interrupted frequently by poorly designed pathfinding and physics interractions. I've watched an animal run circles around a tree trying to get me while I stood still maybe ten paces away. It doesn't happen often, but it is annoying when it does. NPCs will run at trees. They seem to want to get someplace beyond the tree but they can't seem to see it, so they just stick to it and run in place until you chop the tree down. That happens a lot. While fighting, your body will sometimes get tangled up with and enemy's body and you can't do anything until they sepparate. So, you may die a couple times because one monster decided to get freaky with you while the other uses you as a punching bag. That happens way more than it should. In story-mode, you will sometimes encounter invincible enemies. They are invincible because they are part of an event or scene and not supposed to die, but you can't know they are invincible until you try to kill them, at which point they start chasing after you and there is nothing you can do about it, because they are invincible. That is a real pain. The build features (for placing blocks/dirt/etc) has no proper in-game introduction, and unfortunately isn't idiot-proofed. There is a sort of mini-tutorial, but after reviewing it I still had no idea how to use it. I think I am finally figuring most of it out, and now it's fun to use, but it is not intuitively designed. At one point (while trying to build something, though I don't know that is necessarily the cause) the game gave me a 'critical error' and my save-file stopped working, so I had to start the game over.

-YOU MUST SAVE REGULARLY AND USE MULTIPLE SAVE FILES-

Because you may play for two or three days (seriously, not a game for addicts) and then -CRITICAL ERROR- and all your progres is lost.

In conclusion, I happily accept the game's few, though dire flaws, and I'm sure you will as well! =D
And I feel bad about it really, because I bought maybe a dozen games in the steam winter sale and now the rest may never get touched.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alot to say here...
This is a story worth telling: Yours.
This game is in Alpha but shows more promise to be a huge hit than most others I've seen. It is the future and you are on a ship heading to a distant planet to colonize it. As you begin landing preperations you hit something in orbit and the ship crashes to the surface.
You wake on a grass- grass on this planet anyway- grass covered valley. Your escape craft smashed half burried in the new planet's soil, a crew member is injured sitting nearby and you are her only hope to survive. You must hike over a hill in the distance to bring a doctor to help her. Luck has it, he survived as well.
You learn that other escape ships have landed around the planet and you need to find them. To do this you must EXPLORE.
Okay. That is roughly the first ten minutes of the game.
The rest is literally up to you.
You must gather resources from the planet to survive. You have a handy replicator in your pocket and as rewards the people you help give you some scripts" that you add to it
date:
then when you have the needed supplies it can create what you need. It is slightly difficult for example to make a working weapon you may need two or three componants. Raw metal or wood and some maybe refined items. The refined items would have to be made ahead of time from the needed resources they call for. Once you ave all the needed building blocks you choose how many to make and press the button. Easypeasy.
You start with wood tools and weapon and as you find other resources you can build better stuff.
I hate to disapoint but their ar no zombies in this game.
The main currency is meat. You get meat from... Thats it boys and girls! Animals. This planet has alot too. The creatures they have made to inhabit the planet are... interesting. The seem to mostly be six limb based and multi-eyed. Very cool all give a feel of alien and I found myself running to the next hill thinking "Wow
recommended:
what the heck is that?"
You interact with left and right clicks after equiping the correct tool. To fight you left click with weapon. To gather you right click. You have a portable scanner you can use to scan the area around you to look for resources so you know where to dig. Probably alot more I didn't try but what I did manage to check out looked good.
The planet has a day/night cycle and when it gets dark mean buglike creatures that are very aggressive come out to feed. On you. Thats very bad. They emerge from the vast underground caverns that are everywhere under your feet and if you tunnel a mineshaft into one of these caverns you better have some good weapons. And a light source. Because it is dark and dangerous.
All this is played in the single player mode from your computer. An online peer hosted multi-player option is available with play modes of: Adventure

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Put simply: this is one of the most promising sci-fi sandbox games currently on Steam. The graphics are bright, clean, and attractive, and the gameplay is largely intuitive. I find the vehicle building system to be a bit clunky, but the irritation is minor. I have sunk a fair amount of time into this game and I've enjoyed every minute of it. I love building long-distance rail networks to connect interesting points on the map, and I love the random alien encounters!

If you're into early-access games and like the idea of supporting indie game devs, then I'd suggest picking this game up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planets Explorers is a vast world of discovery, creation, and survival. This game is simply too complex to describe in just a few words. This review will be a challenge to write, as the game just has so much to offer.

Planet Explorers is a survival sandbox adventure game developed by Pathea Games.  While the survival sandbox genre might seem oversaturated, Planet Explorers has several features that make it stand apart from similar titles.

First, there is the Story Mode – a single player campaign experience, complete with numerous quests that send you out into the awe-inspiring world to create your own adventure. Collect resources, fight fantastic monsters and aliens, battle giant bosses, explore the huge map…This is the game mode I spent the most time on, and during my time in Story Mode, I learned how the game worked via the starter quests. It showed me how to use and equip items, how to use the crafting system via the Replicator and Scripts, and how to use the very powerful Creation System to make and edit weapons, tools, objects, and even vehicles.

The Replicator is very simple to use. First, you need a “script” for the item or tool you want to create. Think of it as a blueprint, which tells you what resources you need to craft a given item. Scripts can be bought from shops or obtained from quests. Once you have the script for an item, you can use it to learn the recipe for the item indicated on the script. There are Scripts for nearly everything, from weapons and tools, to medicines and clothing.

Next, we have Adventure Mode. In Adventure Mode, you are placed in a randomly generated world with random quests, missions, bosses, landscapes, and enemies. It still has the survival elements of every other mode. What this means is each time you play Adventure Mode it gives you a brand new experience. No two playthroughs will be the same!

Finally, we have Build Mode. This is the mode for the creatively inclined. All the resources you could want, in infinite supply, at your fingertips! There are no monsters or aliens in this mode, and full terrain destruction is allowed. This mode is ideal for trying out new builds, vehicles, and objects with the Creation System.

Wow, that’s a lot, isn’t it? But wait! The fun doesn’t stop there!

Planet Explorers also has Multiplayer! You can host and/or join servers with friends to enjoy the world of Planet Explorers together! Multiplayer has 2 different modes: Co-Op and Versus. In Co-Op mode you join up with friends to explore the world and create fantastic structures and objects together. In Versus Mode, you are put on a team of up to 16 players against another team, each earning points for kills, resourced mined, and objects built.

The game is currently in Early Access on Steam, and is actually an early alpha build. But it is stuffed full of content for you to enjoy! You’d never guess it was in alpha if it didn’t tell you on the title screen.


Recommended!
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely going to have to recommend this one to anyone who happens across it, great way to kill time with your friends (or single player). The game still has a lot of development ahead of it and so far what is available is amazing!

Even once you've covered all the in-game content, the creation system and the player made equipment and vehicles are all incredible, on top of that the developers are actively updating this game (last version was Dec 29, how's that for active!) so if you find yourself bored after the first 20 hours, you will still have lots of fun to look forward to in the future.

In summary, great survival game, good looking (albiet cartoony) graphics, the hunting is fun, the mining is fun, the building is... well, a lil less fun but I imagine they have lots more tweaking to come in all categories. Buy this game and enjoy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's more of an action adventure game than ARK and more of a survival game than GRAV. It does both very well. The game world is interesting, the story is enjoyable, and the building/creation system is impressive (but mostly optional if you prefer to stick to adventure gaming). As you get farther into the game, throw in some colony management that reminds me a bit of Kenshi.

Although the game has been out for awhile it does still have some serious bugs (semi-frequent game crashes). The dev team is still active and the game recently went through an engine upgrade, so there is hope these will be worked out in the next few months.

Overall it's just a lot of fun, if you like survival adventure/creation in a sci fi setting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So my only main concern with this game right now is why did they change how the clustering works with resources you gather. It seems to me that in some patch (while I wasn't playing for idk how long), they decided that resources you gather shouldn't be completely clustered together and should have alot of trash resources, like dirt and stone, in the way. That sense of a realistic touch.. is a bit too much for me. It already took a bit of time and effort to find and gather them. It seems to me as if its take up a rediculous amount more time to gather resources now, making the game undesireable when I feel like I'm spending all day trying to get materials, instead of building the many awesome buildings / vehicles / miscellaneous objects.

Take a look at my hours spent in game and you'll know I'm not fibbing. I seriously had a lot of fun up until now. Now it is a serious grind session. I'll not be playing a game if the work to fun ratio is heavily disproportionate. That being said, I currently will not recommend this game. I will check back in months coming to see progress and hopefully change my mind.

My suggestion to fix the problem would be to either make resource gathering the way it was (heavily clustered no trash in the way), or give us better gathering tools to mine through resources at a faster (or MUCH faster) rate.

You guys would also get extra bonus credit from me if you got rid of the 3ish second 'waiting to stop gathering resources so my character can do something ANYTHING again' wait time. Double bonus credit if you allow me to move while mining.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An enjoyable game with a lot of potential. One of the first of the SciFi themed minecraft-alikes and IMO still one of the better ones, even in it's incomplete state. The crafting system  is particularly noteworthy and powerful and in the hands of someone creative produces amazing results, from vehicles inspired by the Catbus from Totoro na Totori to replicas of weapons from Aliens and just about everything in between.

One thing to be wary of is although it is updating fairly regularly at the moment, it went for about 6 months without updates and little communication from the devs at one stage and that might happen again

I would rate this product 8.5/10 very well done and congratulations on getting it on steam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers is a super ambitious project that will probably reach most goals. Hopefully. The problem for me is not the game itself, or the direction its going in - its with the current state and the price. This is a HUGE project, and so what do you get for your twenty five bucks, right now? In my opinion, you get an unoptomized sandbox that has a moderate-albeit reasonable for the current developement state-amount of bugs and glitches. I just hope they keep going and get it done in a timely manner.

This is an open world, do-whatever-you-want crafting and base building game.

Pros:
+Huge potential (but then again, so does nearly every other EA game)
+Multiplayer could be really really fun in the future, and is even fun now, to a certain extent
+The idea of vehicle crafting is awesome
+The world is beautiful

Cons:
-Personally, I think this should be first-person
-Its glitchy, and in this case, is fairly bothersome (glitching through the world/builds quite frequently)
-It is unoptimized. I can run it at full graphics on my gaming rig, but it sweats.
-I would bet money that developement will cease before the original vision is completely met (not a bad thing, but this is ambitious)

Get it on a sale, and make sure to play the demo first (I think its on their website). Problem is, the open world crafting genre is a super crowded market. You can do better.

Early Access Review

Can't in good conscience recommend this game; it's just too early to say whether it'll be good, but for now it's best left alone.
My entire experience in this game comes from the Story mode, so keep that in mind. My experience so far has been of sticky controls, tentative sound effects, and pretty much no combat system to speak of.

In the game you can design your own weapons and vehicles (the vehicle creation is reminescent of Spore's, or any number of similar games). The system for building weapons is great, it allows for incredible aesthetic maneuverability; it falls a little bit flat when you import your gun/sword into the game and try it out. The ways the game determines what makes a sword have high damage are difficult to determine. The highest damage I've ever managed to reach came from a sword that was a literal block of metal, as big as the game would let me make it. Personally, I prefer SHARP swords, though this may be a stylistic disagreement.

Likewise, my long-barrelled rifle seemed awesome and had great damage, but its accuracy was somewhere between none" and "none at all". This would contradict the little bit I know about real-life guns

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in its early access stages, I have enjoyed this game. The ability to create your own vehicles (ground, sea, and air), and weapons is extremely fun. You can also download ones others have created to use in your game if your design abilities are lacking. You can also save buildings you create, to easily share with others, or if you have the materials, easily replicate again in your game, or even a new game.

Yes, there are bugs. Some of them nasty and will crash you, or stop story progression in single player, or other crazy things. For an early access game, I think they are acceptable at this point as the developer tends to keep us up to date on the known ones. Multiplayer has some... issues. I don't play it often to really know them too much, but lag at times was one of them.

Overall for an early access game, I think they are doing a great job.

This game promises to be one of my favorites for quite some time.  Not only does it have most of the stuff I look for in a game, but it also allows multiplayer co-op so I can enjoy it with friends!

Got this game recently and am rather enjoying it.  It is presently in alpha version a0.8 at the time or writing this, so some of its bugs are bound to work themselves out.

It's part RPG, part voxel builder, part engineering CAD developer, part 4X, part tower defense, all exploration and adventure.  I have been utterly absorbed in playing it for the last few days.  I have one beef with it, though.  Companions.

Throughout normal gameplay, you get tag-alongs, whether you want them or not.  You cannot control them, and they are basically along for the ride.  They are mostly benign, and will even SOMETIMES help with combat (which is nice because they cannot die like the 'hired' companions can).  There are some issues, though.

The first is the pathfinding A.I.  If you are not EXTREMELY careful with where you are going, any following monster bait will get stuck... in a hole, on a tree, in the water, on a herd of turtles.  You can either clear their obstructions so they can get unstuck, or you can build an advanced piece of machinery like a car with spare seats, and HOPE they teleport to the seat.

The next issue with these hoodlums is the fast travel system.  Let's say you have a waypoint that happens to be in the direction of your next quest spot(which itself is a 35 minutes walk), or just somewhere else you want to go for supplies.  If you are babysitting, you are not allowed to use this mechanism in the game without automatically aborting the quest which demands their presence.  Often, they don't go back to where you got the quest, either.  Nope.  They park themselves right there and wait.  And then you have to go find them again if you manage to get the quest once more.

I'm not saying this makes the game bad or unplayable.  But, if a game developer insists on an underwater escort quest, they had better take some special measure to ensure that you don't have to spend an hour fighting water mechanics to dig out a quest giver stuck in a wall.

That's it.  Just the NPCs.  Everything else about the game has drool running out of the corner of my mouth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS:
-Beautiful game on High settings.
-Living breathing world for you to explore without limit.
-Create weapons, armor, and transport, without limit.
-A base/colony system.
-UI is great.
-A nice branching story.
-Epic boss fights.
-Base attacks and raids by NPCs randomly.
-Multiplayer is pretty good.
-Structure building is creative and is familiar to games like Minecraft.
-Mining and digging.
-Character Creation!

CONS:
-Annoying FPS-drops despite my computer fitting the system requirements.
-Technical issues.
-Combat system is Action-Based but still needs to be worked on.
-Crafting is a bit complex.
-No plants/rocks underwater.

PREFERENCE:
-Derpy/Wierd gather animations.
-Shooting system isn't the best.
-Movement system is not what I'm used to.

OVERALL:
This game is great in my opinion for an early access title. The world is really fun and rewarding to explore, and I love the gather animations. The story line is branching but the game is mainly based of the Open-World/Sandbox feel to it. There arn't many biomes yet, like a snow biome. The only thing that brings this game down is it's technical issues,

EARLY ACCESS VERDICT:
7/10

PREDICTED FUTURE VERDICT:
8/10 - 10/10
Once they fix the tech issues and add some stuff to the melee combat system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I waited and waited to review this game cause I had really high hopes for it. But after the long awaited 0.9 update I can't help but write this review, so that maybe I can save others from the useless expense that this game is.
It's new year's day and I'm still on a little hangover so i'll just list what i hate as things come to my mind. Forgive possible mistakes :)
- This game is overpriced. Highly overpriced.
- Optimization: this game will fry your GPU even at lowest settings. I don't have a monster GPU (Radeon Dual-x R9 380) but I can run almost every game at high settings without problems. Here, at fastest settings my gpu still works 100% at 78° with fan speed over 50%.
- Fastest settings will make game unplayable since fonts will become unreadable (really?!?)
- Even at fastest settings I'm having random fps drops and stutters.
- Character creator is always the same obvious placeholder, which was there 1 year ago or so.
- Controls are clunky, would best fit for an mmo in my opinion. By the way combat and object interaction are so bad... to gather materials from plants you have to target the ground under the plant, not the plant itself... really?!?
- Bindings are the most unintuitive I've ever seen. Alt+Y to open replicator menu? Really?!? Yes, you can rebind, but seriously?!?
- Updates come at a slow pace and seem to just introduce more bugs. They've changed the UI several times, onlyu to deliver another clunky and unintuitive UI.
- Music. It's nice for the first 5 minutes, After that you'll want to turn it off, since it's the same super-short song playing over and over again.
- A LOT of backtracking, in story mode. At the beginning you won't have a vehicle to ride, but still the first quests need you to go back and forth between points that are miles away from each other. That's boring as hell.
- The game, at least in story mode, never seems to demand that you build anything. What's the point of giving us the possibility of creatingour own guns and armor etc. pixel by pixel if I can just use the blueprints I find? Plus, creating object, as fun as it may seem at the beginning, it's super time coinsuming and I really cannot see myself craft more than a couple objects in an entire playthrough.
- About creating weapons and such: why should dps of a weapon be based on how much material you use to create it? I mean, why should a gun that uses the same barrel (and so the same bullets, I guess) as another one do more damage just because you've put a lot more wood or anything around the barrel?!?
- Monsters: You'll encounter thousands of identical monsters in each area, which makes the world boring and exploration super repetitive. Now I read they've randomized monster size, so you should have a little more diversity but it's just not enough.

Is it enough?
I really can't see this game getting any better, even in a year or so, plus there are a lot of better exploration and survival games that play, look and feel better than this that I really can't see the point of buying it, so beware...
oh and Happy new year to everyone! =) cheers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet  Explorers is a great exploration, mining and crafting game. It has many cool features, such as a building tool to create weapons, vehicles and buildings in a 3D modelling type engine, which is easy to use, then allows you to import them in to the game to be used.  So creating custom content is easy and fun. The large variety of creatures and resources make it fun and dangerous.
Some of the nicest features are:
Smooth voxel terrain
Large variety of creatures, dangerous or not hostile.
Custom building tool to create custom content and use it in game.
Vast endless  world
Resource mining and scanning is fun and intuitive.
Farming as well as mining.
NPCs you can befriend to help you gather resources, run your farm or otherwise.
A gigantic catalog of recipes of things to build, or  buy.
And of course the currency, MEAT!!!!

Gotta admit after playing 8 hours of it, it is a pretty horribly written game
Whatever the opposite of intuitive is, that’s what this game is... I mean I’ve played some games that took a bit to learn, but once you did, you’ll be like oh yea makes sense (anno 2070, sins of solar empire, space engineers, endless space)

1. AI is pretty bad, there’s no follower debugging teleports to player if they get stuck, I had to double back and tunnel them out in the direction they were running (into a wall horizontally and not in line with my tunnel...)
2. Lots of content, no explanation or tutorials, masses upon masses of unexplained details, prepare to spend more time watching people play the game (tutorial) then actually playing the game
3. Back to horribly written game, I. single player has no pause (I could be wrong), my pause in main menu, no pause in inventory or crafting menu, and being most critters can kill you in 1-10 shots, yup FUN!
ii, main mission has near location marker, but side missions is a total guessing game tortoise mission
iii. during the free the Martians mission an AI decided to run away from the open caged door, whereby making me unable to finish the mission until i teleported back to the same enemy camp, which they got a free respawn and I wasted even more heal/resurrect
Not since eye divine cybermancy (game that uses amost 100% of the keyboard keys as hotkeys) to game has made me so tired of playing it
4. Crafting is a bit of a chore, no level multipier so instead you have to buy schematic or armour which is just a +2 of what you currently have everytime u move on, or meet a new npc.

I'd be happy to change my review once most of they issues is fixed... this game has potential but as it stands id rather be doing house chores, it'll give me more satisfaction effort for payoff then this game gives me right now..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would like to state I have only played this game for a small amount of time, so I am not the most experienced with this game and have not seen all features.

A very interesting concept, space age open world where you can gather rescources and build like minecraft, a somewhat open world like skyrim, and a diversity of species similar to spore.

Pros:
- A simple crafting system, took a few minutes to figure it out, but easy for anyone to understand
- More creatures than you would expect, where else can you be chased by a horde of four-armed baboons then have a bird-like dragon swoop down mid-chase to try and kill you, AND THEN be chased and killed by a wart-hog monster the size of a tree
- The graphics are not ground breaking, but it's something you can appreciate

Cons:
- The character customization is almost non-existant: four faces, eight hair styles (some don't connect to the skull fully), and no different body shapes, but you can change your skin and eyes from white to black from green to purple. You can be a tall oompa-loompa if you want! (that's a pro I guess)
-There are some glitches and graphical errors, but this game is still in early beta I think, you should be expecting that, nothing game breaking though
-Very few things your character can do, for example you can''t run (may be an upgrade, but that wouldn't make sense)

Overall:
This game genre is something I enjoy and it is in alpha/beta stage, if you enjoy minecraft, 7 days to die, or any survival game like that, you will enjoy this, and keep in mind many things will be updated. Of course there will be issues of some nature, but if you're expecting otherwise, don't buy it because you will be dissapointed because you didn't know better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's definitely better than I was expecting. The story mode feels like an MMORPG without the MMO part. Because it's a voxel sanbox game at heart, you can tear the land up basically everywhere from the start of the game. And the ability to port forward to set up a private server for friends is also pretty good, due to the creative aspect of the game. It's PvE or PvP if you so desire. There's things like turrets, jetpacks, and vehicles. As well as a way to create the look of your own swords and stuff. Definitely has potential. The price is a little steep, sure. But you can get your moneys woirth if you allow yourself to.

Only downside I've found so far, is a LOT of things larger than you want to kill you, and early on you can't kill them. And the game is kinda slow paced as you bbuild up. But since you're building up from nothing, I feel thats understandable.

It''s definitely worth a go if you have the money! I have to recommend this one from the bottom of my heart! It has a bit of charm to it. I hope they go heavy on the character customization later in development. The ability to create your own backstory and lore with a unique character each time would help the creative aspect of game I feel, once you're done with story mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since I bought the game I have been playing it for 4 days straight and not even stick of truth was able to keep me engaged so much. This game is basically Minecraft plus with better graphics (compared to other Minecraft-ish games), better mobs (from the cute little woodland critter to giant dinosaur roaming the plain), somewhat better crafting (you can craft modern tools and equipment) and a better story (does Minecraft even have a story except killing the dragon?) Of course there are many aspects that are not on par with Minecraft such as water/lava physics, processing items on other items (putting meat on fire to cook) etc. but we shall see how the final edition will be.


Pros:
1. Best graphics among Minecraft-ish games so far (DON'T YOU EVER COMPARE THIS TO CALL OF DUTY. I AM SICK OF STUPID COMPARISON. CAN YOU DIG YOURSELF A KHAZAD DUM IN CALL OF DUTY?)

2. Somewhat cool story (as a Black Isle worshiper, I can't say I am impressed but the story is at least solid)

3. The world and the atmosphere are awesome. It does give you a feeling of adventuring in an unknown planet with cool (sometimes crazy looking) creatures and weird plants and landscape and ancient ruins.

4. The ability to drive land vehicles and fly helicopters and construct missile launcher/laser cannon etc.

5. The ISO system is fascinating. You can literally create anything you can ever imagine.

6. JET PACK AND GLIDER! seriously, try it out. get to the top of a mountain, run, fire your jet pack, switch to glider at max height and enjoy ;)

7. other minor pros listed by other reviewers


Cons:
some technical issues
1. memory leak crash. It seems quite some people have this problem and I encountered it a few times in the game as well. luckily it does not seem to happen too frequently (for me) and the game autosave every 10 minutes so you won't lose much.

2. lag? not really a con but the game somehow confuses people by including an option in the launcher where you can choose video card. THIS IS NOT WHERE YOU CHOOSE GPU FOR THE GAME. if you are using Nvidia card you have to manually set the game (PE_client) to use your gaming GPU in Nvidia control panel or I guarantee you that your game will lag as cr*p.

3. possible problem with fast travel and sleeping and saving at meteor crate. Some players report bugs that delete all your autosave files when they fast travel from meteor crate and sometimes it involves them sleeping or saving at that location. Personally I didn't encounter any problem but just to put it out here.

4. if you delete your steam and then reinstall steam and play the game using your old save (the same version)... you may see some empty texture in places where you dug. when you jump through the empty texture you will somehow reappear in the sky...

5. I somehow encounter a bug where if you put a roof closely on top of your defense cannons. they will magically appear on top of the roof...

6. multiplayer is still quite buggy so don't expect too much fun from there

gameplay issues:
0. NEED CHANGE ASAP - monster corpses disappear too fast. when you are fighting a pack of monsters, before you can finish the last one, the other corpses may start dissolving already. it is like you have less than 1 min to pick up the loot and it is not cool.

1. NPC SELLS TOO MANY STUFF. you can literally buy everything from NPC with meat. In multiplayer you can even access this one global shop where everything is on sale. I think it is better that only the uncraftable/uncollectible items and some basic starting tools are purchasable.

2. combat still needs a bit of work.

3. can't dig and move at the same time. when you start digging you are rooted.

4. monsters are not very threatening, except that black crab thing. don't know why but black crab can sometimes one hit kill you.

5. can't use weapon while flying with glider (imagine how cool it can be when you rain death from above :D)

6. the bottom of the lake/ocean is always flicking... also the color of your vehicle will be changing randomly if you alt+tab out and get back in the game

7. many objects are not solid, for example, trees. only a small part of a huge tree is solid so you can walk through a tree and fly through a tree but sometimes you can't because that part of the tree decides it wants to be solid and you hit the tree and crash :(

8. the mineral scanner does not seem to work properly when you are moving so you are forced to stand still in order to scan.

9. unlike in MC where you craft items by placing materials in specific ways, this game uses crafting scripts and the crafting script list can be a bit overwhelming later when you collect a lot of them or when you play multiplayer where you are given all scripts at the beginning. although you can search them by types it is still not very convenient.

In summary, a cool game that is still at alpha with alpha problems but definitely playable and just look at the cool features the devs are planning so if you like Minecraft-ish games then try this out. You can't be disappointed, unless you are that kind of player who likes hand holding all the time then why are you playing a Minecraft-ish game in the first place?
voteText: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't even know where to start.  As others have said, this game is exactly what I've sought for a long time.  In a nutshell, they managed to take the positive aspects of various sandbox crafting games and made it fun and removed the tendency to become boring.

I love this game and can't stop playing it.  I can't say the concept of the game is simple because there are so many directions it can go.  There isn't a clear direction on the devs' part, and I mean that in a good way.  They've built a really solid foundation and I'm hanging on the edge of my seat waiting for the next update.

I came across this game looking for something that gives me open-world exploration and crafting.  This game delivers that and then some.  Easily one of the best games I have in my library.

It is tempting to try to compare this to games like Minecraft, Starbound, Terraria, etc., and it wouldn't be wrong to do so: there are a lot of similarities, and feels like some of the devs either worked on one of those or took a lot of inspiration from them, but then again many of these aren't really new concepts.  And in my opinion there's nothing wrong with borrowing ideas that work.

Where this game really delivers is
graphics -- the lack of good graphics made the aforementioned games quickly boring for me;
the Creation Editor, where you can build fairly detailed models from base materials and attach crafted assets to make fairly complicated structures such as custom weapons, vehicles (land, air, AND sea), etc. -- the CE really is a game within a game and I've spent a good chunk of time just creating things there;
and the beginnings of a pretty nice town management" system; you craft the various components of your village
date: invite npcs to live with you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As expected, Planet Explorers is a work in progress, and aside from the bugs, what's there could easily be a stand-alone game.  The number of hours of playtime I have enjoyed is staggering when compared to most AAA titles, so I consider it money well spent.

That said, the game is very rough around the edges, so if you are the type to get frustrated easily by bugs, glitches, and terrible ally pathfinding, you might want to give the game some time to mature.  I lost count of how many times I arrived at a quest destination after a long journey, only to realize that the quest NPC(s) was nowhere to be found.  Most of the time, retracing my steps would lead me to said NPC(s) running mindlessly into a tree or rock, which I would have to destroy to snap them out of their strange trance.  Occasionally, they would get stuck on nothing.  Occasionally, I would get stuck on nothing, too.  This is just the tip of the iceberg.

But if you can tolerate typical early access issues during early access, I think you will find the story is quite atypical--in a good way--for this sort of game, and the city building is shaping up to be something special.  It isn't quite there yet, but Planet Explorers has tons of quests, tons of dialog, and tons of ways to utilize and/or manage your colony.  The voxel system itself is pretty flexible, and once you get used to it (which does take some time) the in-game editor is surprisingly easy to use.  You can make decorations, equipments, and even vehicles.


UPDATE 4/29/2016
Quite some time has passed, and that time has not been kind to this title.  It is nearly as clumsy as it ever was, and other Early Access games have since been released in a worse state only to progress leaps and bounds beyond Planet Explorers.  I am not yet ready to change my recommendation to a No"
date: but I am close.  I suspect I will have to
hoursPlayed: if this is your niche
voteText: I still cautiously recommend it."

Early Access Review

There are things to really like about the game

. More realistic graphics as compared to Minecraft
. Scifi theme

However, I could not get into it. The UI poor and difficult to use. The main elements of the game - crafting, interacting with NPCs, and harvesting resources is tedious. The controls are not intuitive and lacks feedback - the consequence is that combat feels very boring.

It's a great idea with poor execution that made the game not fun to play. And if a game isn't _fun_ what's the point of playing it?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found the game to be quite bland. It has a variety of landscapes and creatures, but they seem to be slapped together with an algorithm that doesn't make much sense and can make worlds seem awkward.

Constructing anything seems needlessly complex, which makes producing anything not so much a challenge but a grinding task. Some may enjoy this but I find the cost/reward to be very imbalanced.

For a voxel based game I found digging to be far too awkward and time consuming, which led me to avoid digging where ever possible.

The vehicle construction is fun and I like the option to design your own weapons, too. I also enjoyed the variety of transport methods like jetpacks, helicopters and motorbikes.

Planet Explorers is mediocre and there are many games that do each element better, but perhaps few that combine them into a singular game.

Early Access Review

Probably the most creative take on the voxel buildersurvival games currently.
Lots of diverse creatures, plants etc that remind me a bit of spore in terms of the many different kinds of critters.
The vehicle (land, sea, air)/weapon(melee,ranged) creation system is crazy... you can build anything you can dream of pretty much.
Single player campign is pretty solid for an alpha.
Multip[layer is OK, although i've never tried pvp.

Still in alpha and apparently they are doing a big rework of the game code.

My main beef with the game is that it isn't farther along b/c I want to play it more. However, it is quite unique and ambitious. Also in its current state I bet you could get quite a few hours out of the campign and multiplayer and the creation system could provide endless hours.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have been playing this game since version 0.53 a year before the release on Steam. This is a beautiful and fantastic game so far and it's not even done yet! Though some of the character animations are not the best, controls are a little weird, and the game can be buggy at times. It can still use some work, after all it is an alpha, that's expected. The problems still does little to dilute the width and breadth of this game. Not only do you get to experience the creativity of the world the developers give you, but they also give you the means to create anything you want and share it. You can literally create your own sword, gun, vehicle, buildings, and even your own community! This open sandbox gives me that sense of freedom that Minecraft gave and more. I'm more excited to see what others will do with this game rather than myself. Either way, I will enjoy it fully. Thank you Pathea Games!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hate early access games. I think that whilst the principle is nice, it's far too tempting for devs to take the money and not deliver on their promises. But this game has interested me from the time I first saw it. I've been looking for a good survival and crafting experience that doesn't rely on multiplayer and all the griefers that come with it. This game offers that in what is already an impressive array of single player and co-op experiences.
Yes it is still noticeably alpha in some areas but the important things all work well and the graphics are good for a game of this type. I'm still discovering new creatures and elements and it sounds like there will be more added by the time it's finished. Building and crafting is very simple and intuitive. I was impressed that the story mode had at least some voice acting, hopefully they finish it off for all the quests and maybe add more than just the 2 or 3 soundtracks they've got.
But yes looking at the other games offering similar experiences I am satisfied that at the moment this one offers the best experience for those who want an exploration game without forced multiplayer. The direction it's heading at the moment it seems it will end up as a combination of Elder Scrolls, DayZ and Minecraft, blending them all together for something unique.
Obligatory throw away line: It's like skyrim with aliens - 10/10""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers have finally come good on all their promises of what this game would be and I got to say it's pretty awesome!!

I know it is going even further forwards but man the game now is just so cool compared to what it was back in the 0.8x versions now at version 0.911 and it has compatibility with my GT 750M, No Full Screen Issues, All brushes and materials can be used, No NPC problems like prior.. sometimes they run into trees and things but quickly navigate around them but it means you can use trees as cover sometimes to avoid direct hits which is a logical step forwards :)

Oh and they brought back First Person View.  I would recommend this game to anyone who has enjoyed playing ARK Survival Evolved, Space Engineers, Minecraft  or similar.. it has a lot of the same functionality but lets you take it to the next level in terms of customisation, invention, exploration and building.

There are plenty of hostile enemies out there in the wilderness and you really do have to survive, you can grow crops.. start up a settlement... get into trades with NPC's or other players if that's your thing.

The only thing I would say is a potential issue currently : The game needs some Officially Hosted Dedicated Servers.. Right now all dedicated servers seem to be player hosted.  Best Multiplayer Mode in my opinion = Adventure Mode : Survival Setting

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not really pleased with my experience whatsoever, for a number of reasons:

-There is no feature in the game that currently feels polished, the voxel terrain, the character/creature models, items, at best the animations are mediocre and everything feels placeholder
-The only selling point is the ISO designer, of which you'll soon realise that there's nothing else much that makes the game worth playing
-The campaign is unengaging and repetitive
-The game hasn't been updated in too long a time for my liking, there is no sense of progress and to be honest I can see the developers abandoning this
-Overpriced for such limited content, however it is going on sale more often nowadays (which is an indication of a number of things i.e. it's not selling very well)

It's like the game has been built around one functionality and that is the designer, without it, then you literally are playing the most generic open-world/sandbox/RPG out there.

This is just my personal opinion, I had expected more development by now considering I bought this around 1 and a half years ago, and it's still the same game pretty much. Look before you buy

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the rare gems that I have seen in the latest trend of Voxel game engines.  If it continues in it's current direction, it will be one of the best games that I have played in the last 20 years.

Machine Specs:    i5 OC @ 4.4 Ghz - Nvidia 660 - 16gb 2400 Mhz
FPS (High Settings): 60+

Summary
The game is in an alpha - so the story line is not complete.  There is about 20 hours of playable story content, and what I have seen is extremely interesting. They have the potential to weave a great story out of this game and are headed in the right direction.

It is a hybrid of a FPS/BF1942 (Yes, the old one) land, sea, air combat - mixed into the crafty style of minecraft, splashed with colony/base management & building.

The game uses a Voxel engine, written in Unity, and while I am not always a fan of Unity 3D based engines (Mainly due to it having such a low barrier to entry - so you get alot of shotty development teams using it), but this game is written so that you would think it's using CryEngine or some custom engine. It has no signs of Unity slowness.

There is a huge technology / crafting tree..  Its not perfectly balanced, but it is so engrossing, that I think they will have no trouble balancing it. The crafting works well.. the UI is intuitive and makes it a good experience.

They have a unique system for 'scanning' for minerals - which makes finding materials much easier and helps with base/colony planning. A great idea.. and it also looks amazing.

There is a great system for crafting your own items/weapons/aircraft/boats/cars - the system is easy to use, reminds me a bit of Google Sketchup, except with voxels - and is fairly realistic in material usage, weight, and physics (IE.. heavy planes don't fly)
They allow you to import models from other users in ISO format - which is a great feature if you are lazy like me and really don't wan to spend hours painting and building a really cool ship. All of the importing is integrated using Steam Workshop - so its' very seamless.. It reminds me of the model importing from Spore.

The multiplayer is still immature - most servers are lowly populated - but it is an Alpha game, so I suspect that will change in the future.  It has a bit of the DayZ appeal in multiplayer, so I think this part will come around as game development progresses.  It offers Adventure, Surival, and Coop modes - but there  is no Coop for Story mode.


Game Development

The game does not feel like an Alpha at all..  The game is fairly stable. I have seen a few crashes due to array indexing issues, but for the most part, its not bad.

The developers have pushed content on a regular basis and seem to be a very worthy team capable of completing this project. I have no fears that my cash used on this project will yield a solid product.

This is one of the few Early Access projects that I have jumped on where I feel like I immediately got a return on my investment. There is a playable demo available at their main site too..  It would be nice if they would add it to steam and maintain it, but that may not be easily done.

Graphics Engine

The game uses Unity - but the graphics are quite nice.  I've done a bit of indie work with Unity 3D and until I read about it on the forums, I couldn't tell it was a Unity based game. The only real visual hint is that the frill is batched, which shows up in open plains areas.

The terrain blending is done to perfection.. mineral types make sense, the textures look realistic to the terrain (IE.. no gold rock sticking up in the middle of the terrain).  The forests are lush and all of the models are well done. The animations are 'ok' - though they could use a bit of work, but it is an Alpha, so no worries on that getting cleaned up.

On my system, it runs very smoothly - renders distant terrain without issue and feels very well optomized. It is processor intensive and uses a large amount of RAM (4gb after playing a while) - so if you have a system with less than 8gb - you will likely see some slowness loading the areas (They make heavy use of caching..)

The minimum system specs are really low.. I don't see how you could have a fun play experience with just those specs.

Game Play

The gameplay is fun..  even the crafting isn't bad (I'm not a fan of minecraft/free form building). It has several game modes, Adventure, Story, and Free Build (unlimited resources) -  so it caters to a variety of play styles.

I see alot of potential in the story - if they can pull it off..   Multi-content base battles.. large battleships (all destructible), very similar to the combat of BF 1942 or PlanetFall.  The best part is that it is voxel base, so the entire world is destructible/buildable.

The story starts off very slow.. I had this game in my library a few times.. thought it was just another voxel garbage game - so I didn't give it much of a chance.  If you play the story, give it atleast two hours as it can be very overwhelming at first and will easily turn you away.

However, consider the story to be more of a tutorial on the interface.  It gets better after you get into the vehicle/guns part and actually turns into an intrigueing story of alien races/who did it/why are we here..

This game is lightyears ahead of Landmark - the only other engine I've seen come close to doing what it does.

Overall.. this is one of the best games I've seen in 2014 and has so much potential and seems to be backed by the developers who can pull it off.

If you understand that the game is an alpha and that your story will most likely be spoiled by playing early (before it is complete) then this a definate buy for your library.

However, I would recommend waiting on the story to be complete as my only disappointment in this game was reaching the point in the story where it was incomplete (I really wanted to play on.. it was addicting, fun and a great experience)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now I want to say that this is a tentative yes to suggesting this game. I love this game, personally, and have found hours of fun just digging and crafting and learning. However: I cannot stress enough that this is an early access game. There's still not a whole lot of content, there are a multitude of bugs, there are some frustrating elements about the gameplay, but overall if you're OK with playing a game still in development then I retract my tentative nature.

The creatures are diverse and interesting, and worlds are colorful and BIG, the technology is a steady advance from swords to pistols to rifles to RPGs. The colonizing element is a lot of fun, the building is something I find unique and more user-creative than other games out there. Normally I get bored with these games after about two hours, but I'm still finding stuff to do here. The gameplay is also relatively stable, I've found a few fatal bugs but nothing that makes gameplay impossible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of potential here. Though it's not quite yet to all be realized.
Monster Hunter is one of my favorite franchises.
I also love Dark Souls.
I also love Terraria, Dwarf Fortress, Minecraft, etc.
I love jRPGs, open world games, survival, exploration, etc.
I also love MMOs.

At a glance, this game seems to be all of those things (minus the massively multiplayer part).
Execution-wise, it still has a bit to go.
I'm aware it's early access, so I'm just hoping all these things get addressed soon.

Large monsters walking about, and you have the ability to craft weapons and fight them which looks like a typical
Monster Hunter battle or a Dark Souls boss -- only mechanics have yet to catch up.
It feels clunky at best. The hit boxes are unclear, and the enemies don't seem to follow a set logic.
Also the lack of real movement options for the player -- rolling being the key one, and the lack of attack animations
that are conducive to this kind of gameplay really pulls the experience down.
I found myself avoiding these fights more than not.
It's not a skill issue, either. I would classify myself as good" to "Very good" at monster hunter
date:
and "well-versed" in Dark Souls.
I appreciate a challenging game and a challenging control interface. I like to take difficult encounters and learn them
until I can beat them untouched and unharmed.
That being said
recommended: I found that next to impossible to do even on the easiest of enemies.\n\nThe method of combat thus far does not seem to be to outskill your prey
hoursPlayed:
but rather to out-tech it with armor and weapons
until its damage and defense becomes negligible to your own.

Exploration is fun
voteText: but could be streamlined a bit and sped up.\nBeing that it is not massivelty multiplayer

votesHelpful: so let the exploration feel fun.\nTune the amount you dig

commentsCount:
I do in fact enjoy this game. I played it a lot before picking it up on Steam. I still continue to jump in and play every now and then.
I am looking forward greatly to upcoming patches.

This has potential to be one of my favorite games.
I'm hoping the developers pull through."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've got a creative bone in your body, you'll love this game. If you loved building amazing things in Minecraft out of materials that you patiently (and often painfully) harvested yourself, you'll probably love this game. It contains a lot of the things people have come to love from creative adventure/survival games and then throws nice visuals and a pretty rad story mode on it like its no big deal.
The game is no way polished and pretty just yet (its early access), but by playing it, you'll realize just how much amazing potential this game has. I've been following this game and playing it pretty casually for the past year and it found it really interesting how connected the developers were with their community - often seeing developers pick up on suggestions from the forums. When the game updates, the updates are usually worth checking out.

My complaints for the game are minimal and will very likely be worked out by release - things like not-so-great voice acting for NPCs in the Story Mode, the incomplete character creation section, the limited/poor sounds and music, having to hold AI companions hands a lot, and generally strange monster AI behavior.

If you're feeling iffy about the purchase, just wait for final release, It'll likely be a different animal worth way more than its current price tag.

When the devs finish this, it's going to be big.  It's already a great game, and it keeps getting better with each build.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This was a promising game, back in the days. The recent update contains enough bugs to completely ruin any game. Collision detection is completely random (this means that there's a good probability of you getting stuck in the air), the controls are awful (some can't even be remapped, because for instance, the tab key doesn't want to be recognised, despite already being mapped), and the AI is one of the worst I have ever had the misfortune of play with\against. I'm sad to say that in the current state, it's not even worth a quarter of what they charge for it. MAYBE one day, when all the bugs are fixed, it will be worth it, but this is not that day.

Edit 29th of May: One of three gamebreaking bugs is fixed - AI no longer terrible. Two more to go, and the thumbs down becomes thumbs up.

Early Access Review

http://www.cublikefoot.com/planet-explorers-first-impressions/

Planet Explorers is a solid third-person exploration game with a lot of content, even in early access.

There's so much to do in the game, so much I've yet to do. I spent most of my time fooling around, fighting random animals, exploring caves, and just generally doing nothing productive. Planet Explorers combines its excellent gameplay with some great ambience, an awesome soundtrack, and some pretty nice graphics. It is in early access, so the game is not without its flaws. I ran into a few bugs while playing, plenty of getting stuck in the map" situations. Hopefully the game becomes more polished as it reaches a release date.

Planet Explorers earns my recommendation. although I still have plenty to learn about the game. Can't wait for an actual release!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, lets sum it up:

Good graphics :
only the animations do not have much variety, but they said it will be fixed in the future updates, and they are really doing it so a 10/10, even if it is not from some big money seeking coorporation like ubisoft or EA GAMES (no offense to them of course).

The music :
Good, i hope they add more tracks to the game, but the main menu song reminds me of Two Steps From Hell, Audiomachine, Adrian Von Ziegler, Thomas bergerson or Jo Blankenburg.
It sounds just soo good to me
! 8/10 for variety, if more music and war songs like to glory or fallen army from GRV music, then it would be a 9/10 or even 10/10

campaign :
IT IS BIG, i mean not big but BIG BIG, i mean, you get like 20 square kilometers to do whatever you want. build a bunker, a big freaking colony, it all depends on your imagination and possibilities. also of recources and enemies and surroundings of course!
a 10/10 for that one! (in my opinion)

Possibilities : ENORMOUS! design your own chair, weapon, vehicle, dreadnought, spaceship, whetever the heck you want, AND USE IT IN SINGLEPLAYER AND MULTIPLAYER! (campaign works too!)
so a 10/10 for that one!

Multiplayer :
Good, 3 gamemodes : adventure, cooperation and VS mode. then we have more generation options for the map like river width and depth, map size to limitless from 4x4 km. so it is big, we have a infinite recource mode to suit your testing(-grounds ;D )
you even have a leveling in multiplayer and a role info, that shows what kind of roles you do and if your good at that. they will expand it with the updates.
a 8/10

Character creation : YES YOU CAN MAKE YOUR OWN CHARACTER!
not like in skyrim of course, but it gets the immersion a bit better done!
hair, skin color , body parts, all you need. not much hair types but a 9/10 for the possibility to even create your own character!

Politics :
That will be implanted soon. no score for that yet.

Colony:
You can have your own colony in campaign and adventure mode!
pretty sweet, because you can build your own buildings and make the interiors to your taste!~make a frigging castle, i don't care, but it has to keep your citizens safe from aliens of all kinds, from small little irritating bugs to titan walking exterminators that destroy everything with they're full armanents.
you can build turrets, upgrade the buildings and make your own custom buildings, that the game will script and use like a base or something else.

A 8/10, if more upgrades would be implanted to the core building and secondary buildings, that would be good, and worth a higher number!

NPC'S :
Well you have citizens in your colony and you can appoint them to do various jobs, from farming to fighting and mining or fishing and cutting trees. some can't fight but they can mine, because they have no strength to do the fighting part. sometimes tough some npc's can't do sh*t and they just eat all your food, soo, have some good NPC'S in your colony!
a reminder : you get your first colony later in the campaign mode, and faster in adventure mode.
try to understand the factors that play when you are leading a colony. like happiness or food and fuel to fuel the buildings.
A 9/10 for this one!

The first person mode will be back in alpha 0.90A .the developers of the game say they will also do more impact improvements and animation fixing, so it will be a big update. and i also understand it can come out later than the 0.90A version. so don't get mad if it is the 0.90A version and you still can't get to 1-st person mode!

And at last a 10/10 for the hardworking people that are making this game for us!~a good game where you don't need to pay 50 bucks for and get only 30 hour's main campaign and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ multiplayer!

KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK DEVELOPERS OF PLANET EXPLORERS!

and I hope I helped you with the preview of this good game!

Have a nice day everyone,
greetings, Daniel.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I originally had this as a thumbs down, but the creation kit has changed my mind.

This game has great potential, but has a number of issues associated with its alpha state.

The game basically has four play modes: -

- Story; which does exactly what it says on the tin.
- Adventure; in which you jump into the world with some friendly NPC's and the foundations of a settlement to build upon once you have collected the prerequisite materials.
- Build; in which you are given free reign and unlimited materials to build whatever you want.
- Multi-player; in which you can set up a server with friends/ family.

The Bad: -

The combat is sluggish, locks you into animations and largely involves swinging a stick in the general vicinity of monsters.

The controls for vehicles (especially helicopters) need a rework (they are simply poorly realised currently).

The build and multi-player modes barely work, the map in build mode has such short draw distances that the use of any vehicle results in you driving off the edge of the map and dieing.

The story mode is the most complete, but it does involve some needless time sinks, and needs a lot more polish.  It also stops part way through while the remainder is in development- but provides circa 20 hours of gameplay currently.

The Good: -

The story mode is fun (but is orientated towards gathering and crafting).

The creation system, in which you can design weapons and vehicles (wheel based or rotor based), is the high point of the game.  Certain pre-made items are required such as a cockpit or energy cells, but beyond this you can create almost anything you set your mind upon.  Of course to use these items in game (other than in the buggy build mode) you will need to collect the materials first.  There are limitations to the system, for example, building a vast rectangle with rotors all over it will give you better overall stats than taking the time to build a realistic, aerodynamic chopper.  Look at the time I have spent in game, most of them have been spent in the creation system.  If this appeals to you, this game is worth buying.

In conclusion; this is clearly an alpha game, and as such it lacks a lot of polish and features, and is fairly buggy.  Once the development has progressed it should be great fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I backed this game on Kickstarter so I've been playing it for a while. It's a lot of fun. I did the storyline a little bit, but stopped because I wanted to do it when the game was finished and free of bugs. But I have plenty of fun just running around digging, building, crafting, hunting, and just exploring. They even showed a Han-Solo-in-carbonite shield that was made in the editor, so your imagination is the limit.

It's Early Access ALPHA and it shows, but it has come a long way in the last year. It's one of the best campaigns I've backed on Kickstarter in regards to getting updates and making progress. They are hard working devs and very open about the development, good or bad. Very good at keeping you in the loop. About once a month they release a new update with a big list of changes each time. I suggest you go look at the updates on their Kickstarter page and view the Changelist in prior releases to see what I mean.

I haven't tried multiplayer yet, but think I will give it a go sometime soon.

I have no doubt this game is bound for(What I would consider) greatness.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoy exploration in games. I usually put on my own music via Google music and enjoy wandering around, getting lost and stopping to look at the world around me. This game is one of the best Ive come across for this type of gameplay.

You're thrown on to an alien world and you have to survive but things are not so dire that you have to constantly fight the entire time. It's paced wonderfully. The alien life is great to discover, plant and animals. Not every mob is out to attack on site. you can walk right up to all kinds of friendly animals, big and small, and get a closer look at them. I really like that.

There is digging, mining, crafting and all the things most everyone is familiar with by now. However, the graphics are excellent and the landscape is a smooth, sloped surface. Nothing like the blocky voxels that most games produce.

I have only been playing this game for a few weeks. Got it about 3 weeks before it hit Steam so I haven't even gotten into the heart of the game by base building, multiplayer, farming and vehicle creation. But going by the first 6 hours i've played it is amazing. A game I can get completely immersed in.

With the updates the devs have planned this could be one of my all-time favorites. I searched many months for a particular game to scratch a beautiful exploration itch and I found it in Planet Exploreres. Buy this game.

The video I am sharing is from the 0.72 alpha version. Before the 0.75 that was the initial Steam version. and the music playing is not in game music.

I am a very big fan of voxel games and sandbox building games and when you add in the 'distant planet in the future' factor, that was a huge hook for me. Gathering and creating is very well implemented and feels nice. The ability to custom build your weapons and vehicles is so well done that it can take hours (If you want to spend that log that is) to make something. This game still is in early access so the only complaints I have are moot because they will be addressed. First, the control of your character is blocking and weird at time, not smooth at all. Secondly, the difficulty is too high when you first start out and then you turn into god as soon as you get any decent weapon. And lastly, and I know I am being nit picky, when it rains it will show up inside your home even if it is closed up. All things said, if you are a fan of sandbox games or voxel games, get this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually write reviews because i feel it is unnecessary; But this time i felt i just had too due to the really undeserved bad feedback this game is getting from people who haven't even played it for a couple of hours.

Planet Explorer is a free-roam, open-world, voxel-based sci-fi RPG game.
You're free to roam and explore a huge procedurally generated world filled with different and colorful flora and fauna, gather resources to survive and have NPC characters join your colonization efforts, and fight off various creatures who'd have you for dinner or as a doormat.

The game has a story mode with a really interesting quest-driven plotline in which you explore the world after a crash landing and eventually gather the survivors for a colonization effort, while facing off with an unexcepted native threat.

The gameplay is somewhat articulate to grasp and isn't all that easy early on - which is why so many people tend to leave the game in the first hour of playing. However, after you get into the kiting and dodging mindset and start getting confidence with the commands and the somewhat wacky interface the door opens for a whole lot of fun.
The game world offers lots of fighting opportunities, but the main treat of the game is undoubtely resource gathering and crafting.
Aside from the standard RUST-like crafting system with which you can craft various basic parts, armors or food, players have acces to a voxel-based editor under which you can create your very own weapons and vehicles. This is probably the funniest part of the game and you're given complete freedom over choice of shape, materials, mechanics and so on. The game then calculates the weight in each resource you've created your item/vehicle out of and prepares a crafting recipe.
I said resource gathering: The totality of the game world can be harvested, broken, dug, chopped down - thanks to the dynamic voxel engine.

Additionally, players can create a colony -think of Terraria NPC hosting mechanics, but much deeper- which will require food, for which you have to hunt or farm, protection, and so on.

Overall the gameplay is vast, rich and addicting.

The main downside is the uncompleted state of the game, which is however kept under a continous updating regibe my dedicated developers. Aside from that, the animations and graphics are kind of wacky, but the gameplay strongly makes up for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is crazy fun, even in it's beta stage. The environments are gorgeous (I LOVE the bioluminescent trees and flowers), the light level at night is reasonably realistic (if you don't have light sources on you, it's really hard to see - which is as it should be imo), and the tools you use to modify the world around you work well also - shovels clear more land than picks, but yeild fewer usable resources; and unlike many fantasy games there is a good amount of medeival-style feel that for me, really accents the sci-fi nature of the game *very* well.  Swords and Guns (including Flare and Rope guns) in the same game at base? YES!

It's not the kind of game that's going to give you a ton of objectives and tedious grinding to do - there is a bit of that in story mode, but it strikes me more like a long tutorial.  I haven't yet finished Story Mode, though - I spend waaay too much time just exploring the beautiful environment and running the hell away from giant flying stingrays with lazer beams on their frickin' foreheads.

The best part, in my opinion, is the ability to start a colony and build it up from scratch, from the buildings to who gets to live there, and gardening/farming in addition to building your own guns and vehicles.  I'm a huge Harvest Moon, Sims and Dwarf Fortress fan, and this game seems to take the things I liked the best about each of those and rolls it into one lovely app. The monsters you fight will even destroy your constructed buildings so you have to be strategic when fighting on your home turf!

I like how there isn't any money/gold in the game, either.  The closest thing that passes for currency is the Meat (the same kind you find on animals), and credits you get once you start a colony.

The only real gripes I have about this game is the lack of detail on the overworld map (Not so bad in Story Mode, but Adventure and Build modes appear to not have any automated mapping ability, it's just a solid blue background with icons on it.  Though you *can* automatically fast travel to your colony and other landmarks the game creates, but at this time you can't fast travel to map markers you place yourself. The other thing I get a little annoyed by is that the buildings in pre-established villages in Adventure mode can't have objects placed on them unless you've built overtop of a space with the Build tools - for example, if you want to decorate a room on the second floor of the default Hotel building, you have to use the Build tools to overlap the flooring and walls, otherwise your lamps and chairs and stuff will go straight through it.

I wish it wasn't such a RAM hog, but it does perform very well aside from that, and the graphics settings actually seem to make a difference.  Very very few crashes.  Overall it's one of my favorites - been following it almost since the beginning, v 0.3x.  It's come a LONG way since then, and the devs are super dedicated.  You can tell this game is a labor of love - it shows!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best voxel based exploring+survival game so far.

Features:
-exploration
-editor crafting of weapons, vehicles and buildings, therefore almost total freedom in creativity
-tower defence
-voxel-digging for resources
-different biomes with imaginative alien lifeforms
-interesting WIP mainstory+tons of sidequests
-quickly evolving Multiplayer mode which gets more interesting every update
-WIP worldgen (also for MP, which features survival and coop modes)
-farming
-resource scanning +gathering
-run, jump, swim, fly, tunnel, glide

Cons: (based on current early access version alpha 0.8.3)
-player movement feels very stiff.
-you can't fly over forests, you need to manouver through trees
-Ingame physics weird, causing animals jumping  weirdly far
-aircraft controlling is extremely basic
-biggest tanks can crash against a tiny sapling
-due to WIP, you are currently playing in about 1/4 of the world, confined in invisible walls.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is SO much fun. I've been having a blast playing it in both single player (adventure and story mode) and multiplayer with friends over the past week. REALLY glad I bought this- for an alpha version of the game it's surprisingly polished, and so far I haven't found any bugs at all which is amazing. I've beta tested a TON of games over the past 15 years and I'm always finding bugs to report, but so far, I've found nothing. The dev's are really quick to update it too when something breaks, they're really on their game which is a refreshing change from a lot of the 'early access' games on steam that don't see updates for months at a time. One evening, the animation for chopping trees broke. I went to sleep, and it was fixed the next day! I got this on sale, but I dare say, it's worth the full price for how much time and care thats being put into this. It's like Minecraft and Landmark had a baby with the space adventures of Terraria/Starbound thrown into the mix. All my friends who play Minecraft with me love this game to pieces and we've actually been playing this a lot instead! The ONLY thing I would add is that I wish there was more weapon/armor variety IN the game, BUT with the ability to create stuff out of voxels (called/saved as ISO's) you can make or download a TON of fantastic stuff that have been made by users, so it's not even a big issue really. The game doesn't have some decor you want? Build it, or find it on the workshop! Absolutly amazing. And so far, the community has been VERY friendly and helpful- I really hope it stays that way.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlanet Explorers is still in early alpha stages but has promise in the already saturated mining/crafting genre.  The ability to create and distribute ISOs (crafting plans) in game allows for endless building possibilities which makes the game unique.  The physics feels just right, especially when flying.  The jetpack, hanglider combo make exploring fun and the boss fights in multiplayer keeps the online play interesting for a little while.  This game is already pretty fun and will only get better with time.  It is worth exploring this planet!
