reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers is to Space Engineers what Starbound is to Terraria.  More invironments, more things to do, and more work required by the designers.  Both PE and SE have volumetric destructible environments and player-built square blocks everywhere, which can be destroyed easily by enemies.  But PE tries to have a whole Story (actually a series of linked quests), AI enemies and helpers, and a world-based environment as opposed to asteroids.  Planet Explorers also tries to have you build up a colony.  It also channels a bit of the MMO Calypso, but with a colony that is just starting, rather than well underway.

Regards A0.7.5.2:
It is Alpha, and Unity based.  Highest graphical settings on OpenGL are not recommended, but DirctX is fine so far.  There is little optimisation as yet, and multiplayer parties should stay together as digging info is not correctly remembered by all clients if they are far apart.  But there is a lot of expectation, and a playable game as it stands.  I just hope that when they say the version number, (currently A0.752, or in the game 0.7.5.2) that they don't stop when the second part reaches 10.  Most basics are there, and now they need QA and more additional stuff regards the world size and colonies.

They work on the game a lot adding new features and enemies, it's definitely a game to get, you can build structures, completely create your own vehicles and weapons/gear. It's a really good game to help support, check out some Youtube videos if you're not entirely sure but I'd definitely recommend it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-NOTE: This review is for a game in alpha!
Very unique game with tons of creative ideas, but as it is in alpha, these ideas lack a lot of flare, and are very underdeveloped. In fact, all the game's ideas (not to mention the whole game itself) is packed to the brim with bugs and errors. The story mode is something I consider awful. The voice acting for all NPC's and keystory characters is annoying, and really feels like something you'd find at a high school acting club. The missions are all tedious, and rarely go beyond the MMORPG tropes of kill X of Y" or "Collect X of Y". This is especially disheartening considering this is a singleplayer storyline
date: and yet it lacks anything to really intrigue me for longer than an hour. The multiplayer is glitchy as hell. Sometimes I'd be able to join a server
recommended: but most of the time this wouldn't be the case. Even when hosting my own server
hoursPlayed: something I've had a lot of experience with
voteText: the connection is very unreliable
helpfulPercent: working around 50% of the time. Now I'm positive this isn't an error on my end
votesHelpful: as I actually have a personal server in my home
votesTotal: have hosted private servers for numerous games
votesFunny: and followed the game dev's official server setup instructions to the letter.... twice. Even if I am able to connect to a server
commentsCount: be it my own or someone elses
column16: in multiplayer
column17: there is no way to control where you spawn
column18: meaning you and your friends will be in entirely different villages and required to shlepp around until you find each other making it very
column19: very tedious. The create mode is the true selling point of this game. The create mode is incredibly easy to use
column20: and almost reminds me of a dumbed down version of Solidworks
column21: a 3D modeling program I used to use quite a lot. That being said
column22: it is still very unrefined and lacks a lot of the flare to create anything more than some basic cars or guns without spending hours in it. There are so many tools missing from the overall creation experience
column23: that many things are so complex to create in this 3D modeling software. This is extremely frustrating since I know that I could easily make a lot of this stuff using the vastly more advanced tools of something like Solidworks
column24: or hell

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had made a review before, saying how good it was... it... really isn't very good at all.
Take it from me, this game... just sucks.
Controls are a NIGHTMARE.
I can't tell if I'm walking or jumping
What does that button do?
The devs say they have a story?
HAH!
Amazingly bad story.
Wherever it is.
The learning curve is insane. You start with a knife and IMMEDIATELY after you kill something they expect you to know freaking calculus.
Seriously, the.. thing creator.. is so horrendously difficult to use, that I stopped trying completely after about the second attempt.
The tutorials are insanely bad. They don't tell you anything.
Now for the good things
The workshop is there
Animations are pretty nice
It can be fun sometimes.


5/10 It just.. really isn't good in its current state.
If you're going to buy it, buy it on sale.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really, REALLY want to play this game!  I started playing when I purchased the early access last year and it didn't take too long for me to realize that I would LOVE it....WHEN IT'S FINISHED!  I did play for about 20 hours or so and decided to shelf it until it comes out.  However that was back in February 2015, almost a year ago now.  There have been lots of updates, yes, but it's still not out.  Who knows when it will be.  I think the game is really fun and has a lot to offer...but I guess for now I will just wait for another year or so and cry about it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This was a waste of money.
I have liked the idea of this game for quite a long time.  The fact that its still not finished and that i cannot play on a LAN with my friend without an internet connection have made me change my review from a positive to a negative.  Im sick and tired, as a paying customer, to make sacrifices in the name of DRM.  I have a detached garage with no internet access that I use for LAN parties.  The trend is these days is to require internet access so that all players have a valid copy.  I understand the desire to get paid for hard work, however, this only punishes paying customers.  For example, Diablo 3 requires an internet connection for the offline single player campaign.  Horribly intrusive for the paying customer hoping to play on the go, but a hacked version was released on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ within hours of the release of the game that didn't require an active internet connection.  The pirates actually got MORE playability on this one.
I will not dig a 200 ft trench to install lan cable to my garage, nor will i try to get a stable wireless connection to transmit that far.  I will simply sulk, leave bad reviews and do better research before I buy a game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYesterday i came back to this game after a year or so away, and found it seemingly unplayable compared to older versions. I posted a bad review urging people to stay away from it until the devs fix the issues i was having (unresponsive keys/mouse) then something happened about 15 minutes after i posted that makes me change my recommendation to thumbs up. I got a message on steam from one of the devs (very quick response time) who told me how to solve the issues i was experiencing... very easy fix... reset key bindings to default ! I had never thought to do that as i have never changed keybindings on the game, but low and behold, instant fix. I have over 100 hours on this game and was / is among my favorites. Keep up the good work on this game and I want to thank developer zede05 for the quick response and help to make this one of my favorite games once again. VERY much recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Without a doubt the best game I have played of this genre! It manages to captures the essence of frontier planatery exploration while allows for a very playable game. When they say it's a sandbox game, they mean it. You are not restricted in playstyle and can easily play the game in so many different ways. You can play it like a basic action game, running around and hunting monsters. You can play it like minecraft, building elaborate structures. You can play it almost like spore, creating interesting designs. Or you can even play it like a management game. The wealth of possibilties was something that really took me back.

What is most important however, is that it is still an early access game, but it doesn't play much like one. The game feels quite robust and has less bugs and problems than in some post-released games. This does not however, mean there is no work to be done, it is not finished and can only really get better. Would definately recommend this game, absolutely amazing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYes!!! It's Cheap only 24.99 and you get nice graphics and its multiplayer. It's in some sort of Alpha stage right now but for what you pay and what you get, its crazy fun, its like a mix of Landmark and minecraft meets like...starbound but 3D. It so far runs real smooth on my system. You can save your game progress and play with friends, you start in a world similar to how you start in survival mode in minecraft, you explore, you collect build and kill big angry monsters before they kill you. Day and Night cycles, the shadows and lights and effects are really nice. It's by no means the best graphics out there but for a voxel based game, its definatly a fun experience!!! Grab a group of friends and please give this game a try, for 25.00  you won't regret it!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start with I started playing this befor .55 alpha and it has come a long way and still has a way to go and remember this is STILL ALPHA at the time of this review.

Where to start first the devs have added 3 zones from the time I started playing and still have more to add with ea area having a feel that makes them stand out. I will warn you stay away from the story as there are buggy spots and this isnt finished and having to restart to get them to work when added lated makes you play through it all again  Learn the ropes of the game and just use the quests to start your self out with that. I have restarted too much but alpha is all ways like that so this is just to warn you not to burn your self out.

The build system or what can I fly/drive around or make today system gives this more than just I little jump on any game out there right now. The ISO's (look this up for player made creations and I hope steam workshop soon), has many built for you just to download and add to your game. It ranges from the flyer to ground tanks, fun for every one and new guns, swords, shields you name it, some one has thought up a way to add it in or if you ask they mite add what you want.  With the ISO's just a build file this can be shown or given to any one and you can say hey look what I made today, this = a comunity of builders that will keep this game alive for a long time.

Have to say a tryed muti player when it wasnt working in older builds and havent tryed it on newer builds so I wont say anything I have been told it runs better and most problems have been solved.  Alpha build is where you fix problems and they are fixing it, you will have to try this your self.

I keep coming back to this game and love its on steam now, so I know when a new build is up. I try new ideas explore and enjoy how this is as close to realism a vox game has come so far, well it still has lasers and cannons and space ships to new planets and .... yea not that real but still fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is already quite a lot of fun in alpha, so if you have cash to spare it's worth the high price tag. There are definitely some glaring issues, mostly combat and small map sizes, but the issues shouldn't be too hard to fix before the full release and when they are it will most likely be the greatest sandbox/exploration/crafting game ever made.

I could spend hours just in the gun/sword/vehicle creation tool the game has as well, it's probably the best part of it so far despite having some rough edges.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first hour of playing the game and I'm impressed with the open world, NPC interaction and the quest system. I’m just starting on the crafting tree, once you learn to click on the scripts then you can replicate items – it’s a breeze. Easier than Minecraft in that you don’t have to select each resource, drag it to the crafting table then craft it. On the Con side the character movement controls – it’s not as immersive as minecraft. I might have missed some control configuration but I’m definitely do not like the way it’s done. I’ll keep playing around with to see if it’s a configuration.  Also chasing down NPC to talk to them and missing them and having to chasing them down again was a pain – funny – but a pain. ;)

Overall I would recommend it (if the movement controls can be improved) the game has a lot of potential.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Who wouldn't recommend this game? o.o';
Like for real..? Who wouldn't?.

The game is great, and for a price of 22,99.. hell yeah.
I've been playing the game for 44 hours so far, and I can't get enough.


%Environment-

The world itself, feels incredibly smooth.
The leaves dancing around, as you walk through the forests.. just awesome.
It sort of.. brings the place more to life. It's all about the little things :3
And let's not forget the nature..
They've done a really good job, since it's set on a different planet, many lightyears away;
It'd only be logical to make a new type of nature, instead of the basic trees and flowers we see everywhere.
Let's take one of the tree's as an example :D - The C which fell. <- apparently what I call it >:o.
Like, it's literally a tree formed as a C, but with both ends in the ground; with a few branches sticking out here n there.
I personally haven't seen that one before.
And the awesome flowers which again doesn't seem like everyday flowers, but neither too fantasized..
Some are quite huge and others are tiny; but they're all pretty well made.

For an alpha release, this couldn't possibly get any better.


%Characters & Customization-

I'm all in for customization and eye candy.. I'm just that type of person.
But in this case, it actually doesn't hit me as hard as in other games..
The Character Creation System isn't too advanced(at the moment.)
But you're still capable of giving your character a personality.

Currently there is;

-FEMALE-
5 Female Face Types.
15 Female Hairstyles.(+any colour) (not bad for an alpha, huh?)
1 Female Voice.(no menu)
1 Body Type. (Though you can colour your skin to almost any colour you want.)
And an empty Other" tab(wonder what'll be added here :D)

-MALE-
4 Male Face Types.
11 Male Hairstyles.(+any colour)
1 Male Voice.(no menu)
1 Body Type. (colour applies here too of course.)
And the "Other" Tab.
-
The characters aren't super HD looking in the Char Creator.
But in the game itself
date: they're quite good looking.\nPlus with the visually shown armor types in-game
recommended:
you won't need much more :).


%Game Modes-

For an alpha release
hoursPlayed:
they sure have a lot for us to toy around with....
The game currently has three -(+VS Mode online)- game modes in the alpha release;

Story Mode (you follow the storyline + free roam..)
Adventure(+ VS Mode online) Mode (open world free roaming
voteText:
where you decide what to do)
Build Mode (exactly what it sounds like..)

I won't go indepth with the game modes themselves..
Though I will say that my favorite mode
helpfulPercent:
is Normal Adventure Mode(non-VS) online.


%Creation System-

This feature right here... FREAKISHLY AMAZING.
It's like an in-game simple to use modelling program.
So far it's possible to make:
Swords.
Pistols.
Rifles.
Small vehicles.
Larger vehicles.
Helicopters.
VTOLs.
Battleships(30x60x28 meters..'if i remember correctly..') (flying ones.. not a boat D:)
And Tiny
votesHelpful:
Medium and Large Objects.

And the best part of this feature? you can import your creations right into the game.
Well
votesTotal: yes in singleplayer
votesFunny: you might say.. NOPE.\nThe online multiplayer servers have an upload/import function
commentsCount: when you launch the creation system within them.\nAll of the creations require their respective materials to be made though.\nEngines
column16: metal
column17: sword hilts.. fuel.... etc.\nAll something you have to have in your inventory
column18: before you're able to import your creations.\n\nNow
column19:
this feature is too big for me to indepth with.
It's something you have to toy around with.


%Minecraft Comparisons-

Here we go.. another minecraft clone. Right? - Oh hell no!!#$@&^
This epic piece of work deserves its own place in the spotlight.

I don't get why every single game
column20: where crafting and resource gathering is available -\nhas to get compared to Minecraft.. It's truly sad to see the current generation of gamers and casuals..\nAnd for some reason
column21:
everyone seems to forget that roughly 65% of minecraft is community made.
I know of nobody who play Minecraft Vanilla singleplayer/multiplayer anymore.. Nobody..
Everyone plays on modified servers which were made by the community..
Notch made the base game
column22:
we made the rest.


%Review-

This is only a lite-review.
I will do a proper in-depth review of the game
column23: once it has been released in it's 'final' state.\nExcluding updates of course. Well
column24: perhaps a hotfix or two
column25: after the release. (something always go wrong..)"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm well into the single player story game and loving it.  While the story elements aren't very deep yet and a few of the voice overs are a little plain, the game does have some thought out lore which is decent. I can't wait to try it with a friend in multi-player

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though it is in early access, it still has many more things in it than other builders do.  You can create vehicles to travel/battle creatures, manage colonies, setup automated defenses and attract monsters to them.  I have been playing this and EQNext.  Neither game is finished, but this game has many more features.  There are some stability issues and it has not been optimized for performance, yet.  So, if you have a low end PC, it may be wise to wait until it releases.

Fast forward 2 years, and I'm still hopeful it all comes together.  The crowds are growing turgid with negativity by spewing comments about how much money they have pulled in.  People obviously do not know how much developers and designers cost.  A Jr. Dev, that will work at a much slower pace and produce bugs, starts around $60k/yr.  A Sr. Dev, that should work much quicker and more efficiently has no necessary cap on their costs, but it usually floats around the $100k/yr area.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a nice sandbox game, this one can be good fun to you. I actually bought it a few days ago and have a playtime of 30 hours, that's more than with some high budget games.
Sure, it's an Prerelease but it already contains tons of fun and works very stable for a prerelease. I love building custom cars and flying battleships.
I prefer the adventure mode, where you got all recipes but have to gather resources. It has a random world generator, so every game can be different. Story has no random map, but it's a nice world to explore.
Building your own colony and inviting NSC to settle there is a great feature, hope this one's get extended further.
For my opinion, it is worth the money I spent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impression is pretty incredible. Glorious 3D environments with vibrant flora and fauna sprawling in all directions greet players first thing out of the gate, complete with a skybox full of planets and stars at night. The spirit of adventure takes center-stage, with a massive open world to explore and several modes of travel with more on the way. System to design custom swords and guns is implemented and looks versatile, but seems to require some getting used to, as with the UI for designing and erecting buildings. Running and jumping animations are somewhat clunky, and character customization is minimal for now, but these things are all minor problems surrounding what looks like a game with vast potential. Worth the price tag even during alpha release.

In words closer to my typical format; it's the margarita produced if you shoved Phantasy Star Universe, Monster Hunter, and Starbound into a blender with tequila and a bunch of ice.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game can be a lot of fun if you like open world crafting type games.  What is particularly unique about it is the cad-cam style crafting interface that theoretically allows you to build anything you want out of your own user-defined shapes and utilizing in-game mechanical and electrical components.  In addition to crafting, there is resource gathering, hunting, enemies to kill, and discovery of new areas on the map.  I would probably play this much more often but as building and harvesting take a lot of time, I have kind of shelved this game until it is a little more updated.  Its a bit of a pain to build something extensive and then have to start over because of patch incompatability.  If you are patient about patches and love these kind of open world survival games, I would recommend this, but I might also suggest waiting for a more complete build.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely love this game - even at the lowest graphic settings the world is breathtaking.
Once you get the hang of the controls they are fairly intuitive - the build function and ability to make your own custom objects and vehicles is a big plus too.
The wide range of biomes and almost complete destructibility of the world increases the 'real feel' of the game, and the crafting system (replicator) is one of the best I've seen yet.
Only downside possibly is that it is very graphic intensive - I have a fairly high spec mac and i have the graphics set to their lowest setting.  It is a bit buggy but I would consider a  must have  for anyone who likes a good sandbox adventure game and is looking for high customisability.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers is a great game with amazing potential - much of which has already been realised in spite of the game only being in Alpha, with the ability to create all sorts of gizmos from cars, boats, planes, helicopters, buildings and even the kitchen sink - literally. You really are only confined by the limits of your own imagination.

Having been playing the single player mode since Alpha 0.81, there are issues in multiplayer that really need addressing (A0.831 being the latest version at the time of writing). Also given that this is still in Alpha I cannot stress that these are issues that will eventually be resolved in due course.

Undoubtedly the biggest issue thus far has been that hosted servers do not always save your progress. You can spend hours upon hours creating things (which luckily you can save as isos to use again at a later date), but if you're unfortunate enough not to be able to do this and your server fails to either save or to appear on the server list, then all your hard work will have been for nought.

The game also has a tendency to spawn your character underneath blocks you've already placed, which is no better demonstrated than logging into the game and finding your character face-deep in the dirt under your house. This latter point is obviously an issue regarding optimisation that can easily be resolved, though servers not saving your hard work is a much more serious issue.

While single player 'story mode' and multiplayer 'build mode' seem quite stable, multiplayer 'adventure mode' on the other hand seems very buggy by comparison.

In spite of all this however, I'm very happy to say that the potential of this game is such that it warrants further and continued interest on my part*, though I may update this review as and when necessary. 4.5/5

--------
* The game has been so promising that I bought extra copies for my friends.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI played the Story mode twice and will again when there's another patch, or sooner if I can't wait. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't normally do reviews for games or anything else for that matter but after having played this game for over 400 hours as of posting this I have to say this game is becoming one of my favorites and it isn't even finished yet. The developers have put a lot of work into this game and that has come a long way since when I picked this game up a few years ago.

The ability to create new weapons, armor, vehicles, and items to place around your colony is taken to new heights in this game. There is a built in modeling program to design things to make your gameplay one-of-a-kind for you.

While there are still a few bugs in the programming each update they have released has greatly squashed this number as well as adding significantly more content to the game.

I would recommend this game for anyone who likes voxel-based games or is just looking for a nice open world sandbox game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEDIT/UPDATE: Something new that really chafes me that I *HAD* to add to my review!  I've tried to wrap my head around it, and even though in some ways I can see the pros, ultimately I have to feel as though it's in direct violation of the Early Access Program rules of Steam.  Now, I'm not trying to go out of my way to make trouble for the developers of this game... I truly think it has tons of potential, tons of possibility to do well, and I just wish they'd get their heads out of the butts and iron out the core features like CONTROL INPUTS for the CORE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE GAME (and before anybody says that controller-support isn't a core function... it's LISTED in their INPUT section under the CONTROL menu, with some Joystick buttons even listed as defaults, while only half of an entire gamepad/joystick works, but also interferes with Xpadder/Pinnacle working properly -- there are quite a few people that have medical issues, myself included if you count aches/pains from old age, that can only comfotably game with a controller... most times I even use a controller to navigate through the OS and such... Unity HAS built-in controller support, so either iron it out, or turn it off so people can use XPadder or Pinnacle!!!  Buyers have been asking/begging for it for OVER A YEAR NOW!).  Anywho, here's what's chafing me... Steam's Early Access is about ANYBODY that pays for early access, gets to experience the game as it goes.  Planet Explorer's decided to make an Alpha-Beta team I guess.  And no, I'm not butt-hurt that I couldn't be on the team"... as far as I know you just have to opt into it
date: and anybody in EA can do that as far as I'm aware.  It just blows my mind though

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played some of the Single Player mode.

Like most negative reviews, game has potential.

It is in Alpha and I bought it more to support the project.
I'm hoping somewhere down the line it becomes a great sandbox but
at the moment you really feel like a tester then a player.

The environment is very 1D and the NPCs looking very generic.
However some smart interactions with some creatures chasing others
but nothing worth shouting about.

Watch some online gameplay and make up your own mind, but don't expect any
epic gameplay. More of a supporting/tester role.

PS- Not sure if it's because the game is still in Alpha production,
but it is deceptive and very graphics heavy. I run a mid-high gtx850m and I m able
to get almost all games on HIGH smooth and a few on ULTRA. I tried running this
game between its HIGH-ULTRA settings and a 25-28 seemed to be the limit, which
was strange since playing the actual game you can't really tell from the visuals
where the loss of frames is coming from.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only tried the Story Mode so far, and after that, I don't know if I'll be up for trying the other modes.

The game has potential but it's still very early to determine what the end result will be. Playing, it feels like the developers are still unclear on what they want to do with some features. From what I've played, quests have been simply going from point A to a very far point B then back, or gather X amount of resources A, B and C, or a combination of the two. They are long, tedious and do little to keep you wanting to play more.

The crafting system is decent, but very early on, you'll get very complicated scripts that require you to create many different materials from many different resources in order to create a single Item. It wouldn't be so bad, if resource gathering was fast and entertaining, which it's not. early tools take ages to gather resources, and you're stuck with them until you figure you have to buy more scripts from an NPC.

The combat system is barely worth speaking about. If you don't notice the little enemy health bar that appears in the upper left corner of the screen, you won't even know if you're landing any strikes or not, until either you or your enemy are down.

You can put items for use in the 1-9 bar, a la Minecraft, and it works well, but the only way to know which Item you have equipped is by looking at the square left of button 1, which shows what you're currently using. I guess that's ok, but it'd be less confusing if it just highlighted the Item you've selected. Another problem is that if you're using a sword and Shield and you change to a pickaxe to do some mining, when you switch  back to the sword, the shield will stay unequipped, forcing you to go and equip it again, which can be annoying considering how you can be attacked at any time.

One other problem I had is that throughout the time I spent playing, I felt like I was doing something (or rather everything) wrong. Following the questline brought me to face enemies against whom I had no chance. I constantly wondered if there was something I missed, something that should have prepared me for the challenge, but there seemed to be nothing there.

Overall, the game has potential, but I cannot recommend it to anyone, simply because it's too unfinished. I wish I had waited a year or two more to play it in a much more polished state. I know I'll have to wait at least that long to come back to it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game seemed to have a lot of potential. I was really curious as to where it might go, when I bought it nearly a year ago. I was waiting a few promises made by the devs, such as more of the neat stuff in story mode made available in adventure mode (with friends) before buying it for other people to play with me.

But since then, I've just seen one deadline after another pass by. Frankly, the devs are starting to seem disorganized and incompetent. I don't know what's going on over there. I would not buy this game until at the very least, the devs managed to finally finish 0.9, and see where the game stands then. I wouldn't be surprised if even more features get pulled from 0.9 before they release it.

Early Access Review

I have been really hesitant about early release games, since alot of them recently have all but died (day z). but i got this on a whim, mostly because i had extra steam cash to spend. but truthfully, IM GLAD! for as little as i was expecting this game has blown me out of the water, yes the animations still need some work and the item (prebuild) customisation is a bit confusing (at first).
But for a alpha game, im 7 hours in and when i was about to get off, i realised i only explored 2 of about 9 zones on the map. this game when done is going to be an amazing 50+ hour adventure. and if you have to justify not spending 15$ for 50 hours of fun, you REALLY must be tight on cash.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLikely the best voxel sandbox game to come out to date, Planet Explorers gives the player unprecidented freedom to design weapons, vehicles, and buildings; voxel by voxel. Lush environments, a great story line, active ecology, and the ability to harvest from almost anything you can see on screen make this the most compelling sandbox game currently available. As of this writing; there are a few technical issues, none of which are show stoppers (indeed I have only had one crash ever) and most of the bugs are cosmetic in nature. Not bad for a game in early alpha. This title shows great promise as a freeform Adventure RPG and creative sandbox experience. I'm hooked and impatiently awaiting a0.76!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With 20hrs under the belt I can safely say that this game is fantastic.  There is so much to do and so much life to the game.  I will break it down by features.
Graphics:
The graphics are great.  There isn't as much control over what features pertaining to graphics are used but enough to make sure your system can run it properly.  At full quality it looks stunning.  Light permeating through tree leaves, a nice not-over-done bloom effect, AA, it all works great and runs smooth.  Very pleasing to the eyes.  The voxel engine handles very well and even with an older video card, the game handles it all very well and even displays very far into the distance (im using a nvidia 560ti).    The weather is handled very nice and looks good.  Night time is actual night time.  You can hardly see at pitch black and need a torch or light.

Characters:
It is great that they allow you to create your own custom character like sims or elderscrolls games.  The NPCs are active but not to the extent of say skyrim where they have jobs.  They sort of just stand around and walk here and there. You can talk to them and get a lot of story background which is great.  You can even enlist some of them to fight beside you and you can equip them with armor and weapons and whatnot.  The mercenaries have their own set of special skills too.  Some are great with swords and others with guns and so on.  Adds nicely to who you choose to follow you.  I like that the mercenaries reappear beside you when you get too far from them.

Story:
Great story line.  Makes you want to learn more and more about what is going on.  This coming from a guy that usually is not interested in story.  I found myself wanting to know what happened.  That doesn't happen often at all.

Sound/music:
The sound was good.  The music adjusted appropriately depending on where you were and whether or not you were in the area of a hostile enemy. It was a little glitchy but I've read they are fixing that.  Sound effects fit weapons and whatnot.  It could use more attention to vehicles and sounds but overall still good.

Quests:
The quests are your run of the mill quests.  They are good and add to the the story.  They don't always feel quite at all like a grind.  Some can be, but that is normal it seems.  Other quests are more detailed.  I will say there are some bad bugs with some of the quests that require a npc to follow you.  That npc is prone to get stuck at a tree or rock and unlike the mercs that you hire, the quest npcs don't reappear at your side if you move too far away.  I have found that if you have a quest npc with you, if you bring out a vehicle and get in it, the npc will rellocate to your vehicle which is an unintended fix.  This leads to problems early game especially when you are travelling long distances.  When you have quest npcs with you, you can't fast travel.  If they get unexpectedly stuck in a tree you have to travel all the way back to retreive them.  This can be frustrating. There are some quests that you receive early in the game that won't be completed until later.  Many have had problems with this.  I imagine it will be fixed in later versions given this game is only early access.  SOme quests are a little buggy but that is mostly due to the fact that npcs end up getting stuck in random places.  There was one quest involving two npcs and I couldn't complete the quest because one of the npcs randomly got stuck in a mountain side and I couldn't get him down until I dug out the mountain side.

Building:
The game contains a lot of building which is great.  Kind of like minecraft.  You can make your own weapons and vehicles and whatnot.  You require schematics to build things and sometimes require to build one thing in order to build another.  It doesn't get overly complicated though.  The difficulty of the build is often representative of the usefulness of what you are building.  For instance, you can't just easily build a helicopter.  It requires you build a cockpick, rotors, engines, energy cells, etc.  It is a very intuitive building system that takes a little time to get use to but once you are it is very easy to use.  There is a lot of fun to be had.  A lot of creativity that can be used.  I will say the game could do better at helping you understand the proper needs of a vehicle.  I made a dune-buggy type car and I had all the pieces but in game I got this red text at the bottom that told me the car is overpowered or something.  It never really told me why it was overpowered or how to fix it.  The car still worked fine as it was.

Enemies:
There are a lot of animals and enemies in the game.  Many of the animals are docile until you attack them which is nice.  Some of the animals are hostile from the start and it is fun and interesting to see which animals will attack on site and which animals will run right beside you.  The enemies are dangerous too.  Some prefer to sit back and snipe you.  Others will come slinging swords and whatnot.  Some will even mount turrets and will sling rockets and bullets at your face.  The animals and enemies come in all shapes and sizes and the size of the mob usually indicates how dangerous they are.  There are a few points where you fight some extremely large enemies and they can prove quite hard to defeat.  I will say the ranged mobs seem a lot more easy to conquer given they can be dodged easily.

Overall:
Wonderful game with a ton of potential.  It already has a great deal built into and most of what will probably come from later versions is just more content.  I hope they fix some of the not-so-obvious bugs mentioned above (I am sure they will).  Creating your own camp and playing tower defense was really fun.  Being able to craft cars and helicopters and then drive them around was extremely fun.  The game does a great job easing you into the features and concepts of the game.  Very fun and leaves you wanting more (it is in alpha so that is to be expected).  I look forward to future updates and highly recommend you buying this game now if you enjoy rpg and open world sandbox games like terraria and minecraft.  There is a lot of replayability built into the game and right now about 20hrs worth of straight story line with some random quests thrown in.  It is a very balanced game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game for a couple years now, and it continues to get better and better. It takes a bit of time to warm up to it, but if you give it a chance, you'll find it a deeply satisfying blend of RPG, sandbox, base building, exploration, crafting, and open world survival. The AI NPC's are a fantastic addition, as well as the built-in object editor, where you can download patterns other people have created from within the game. You get to create your own avatar and customize gender, hair, eyes, skin, face, and clothing. That's a HUGE plus in my book.

If you're looking for an alternative to Minecraft with better character and creature models, better environmental graphics, more streamlined crafting and building, vehicles, NPC followers, objectives, quests, and more diverse and interesting types of weapons, this is it. Truly an amazing game, even this early in development. I can't wait to see where it goes next.

My friends and I have already had quite a bit of fun with this in multiplayer, although at this stage the features could use a bit of work. It would be nice to have a more fleshed out multiplayer story mode. But even as it stands, it's a ton of fun.

Devs, if you read this, your idea of enhanced NPC interactions like marriage and procreation? Yes yes! Do it! Also, it appears difficult if not impossible to get NPC followers to heal themselves. Please fix that! Thank you for making such an excellent game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

October 16th, 2014.

Planet Explorers is a game with great potential.  However this is how every Early access game starts out.
As of right now I can say it -IS- worth the asking price, as the game is fun regardless however I do have a few personal contretemps regarding the game.

The biggest one being it's been far too long without an update/patch.   They have plenty of communication but most games I play with early access pump off a patch a month, at least.  But rather then randomly pointing out fails and wins, I'll make a list.  Just remember, this is MY personal opinion, an opinion someone else might share.


Pros

-  Scenery is beautiful as is, though after a few patches, assuming it'll be even further improved, makes me excited to see just what amazing wonders this game can pull off.  Even the Random adventure mode is pretty nice on the eyes, day or night.

-  Although limited, I DO like where they're going with the combat system.  A little clunky, yes. But it feels less like the other generic fps crafting survival games and instead takes a 3rd person approach which makes the game feel far different. making sure not to force you into a choice between this game and one just like it.  You can easily enjoy both to the same extent without feeling like you made a redundant purchase.

- Being able to create and download blueprints for other vehicles and buildings.  I can't possibly praise this feature enough.   Not only can you duplicate something you spent hours making, but you can tweak a design others have already imagined.  To construct the masterpiece is even easier, only needing the basic materials it lists to make it.

-  Terraforming.  What turned me off about most crafting/terraforming games is the blocky or jagged earth you're left with when you take a pickaxe to the dirt.  When something looks too reticules, it takes you away from the immersion and just makes you want to get the digging over with.  Not the case with this game.  Not only does everything seems smooth and manageable but you can find yourself digging into a chasm below, falling into a dark cave, water to your waste.  Lighting a torch you would stand in awe at the amazing/beautiful situation you've found yourself.

-  My personal guilty pleasure.  I enjoy nothing more then making a defensive structure, armed to the ♥♥♥♥ with rocket turrets, jobbers.  Only to use a craftable item that lets you call out the most dangerous creatures to challenge your amazing armada.

CONS

-   The music in the game is dreadful.  I found myself disabling music in-game, tabbing out, opening YouTube, just to find my own adventure music to play in the background.   (this is obviously easy to counter with a quick patch)

-   Turrets shoot at the ground, walls, friends, or whatever, trying to shoot an enemy that might be behind said obstacle.  Because Turrets have limited ammo, this is bad... very bad.

-  Lacking plenty of sound effects.  this is to be expected though.  Since this is on the same topic, I have to mention that the voice acting in this game is dreadful. it honestly makes me roll my eyes out of their sockets when I actually try and grasp the storyline.

-  Lacking a worthwhile tutorial.  They are working on one now but I already know they're going to mess it up.  No one likes to sit/play through a tutorial for 15 - 20 minutes.  people like to see what they can do on their own, with the option of learning should they be stuck or inquisitive.  Making a colony for your people as an example, is needlessly complicated .  Not so much setting up a colony, but rather utilizing it.

-  Being stuck on an island small as my ♥♥♥♥ in adventure mode.  I just don't understand it.  I loaded multiple games to see if it was just an unlucky seed generation but no, I was doomed to be an island



Again, MY opinion.  Love it or hate it but let me know if you have anything to add because my perspective CAN be swayed.  From the bottom of my heart, I hope this game ends up being everything it was meant to be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very well made game, especially for alpha. There are still a few bugs, but from my experience (20 hours on record as of this writing) none have been game breaking. So the good and the bad:

Good:
Good sandbox with a story line
Decent graphics and well textured alien fauna and flora"
Powerful item maker (although somewhat limited) allows for creation of your own weapons/vehicles
Vast amounts of resources that can be combined into other parts etc making for a rich and rewarding crafting system
Seemingly active Dev team

Neutral:
Ok voice acting
date:
not the best but still not bad
Sometimes NPC's can be annoying or in your way other times very helpful
lack of ability to make your own armor types (in creative mode)
Adventure mode (the free roam survival) is somewhat lacking in depth
Build mode devoid of NPC's and animals
Still in Alpha

Bad:
Can be somewhat glitchy (rubberbanding NPCs
recommended:
sometimes textures disappear from ground)
Adventure/Build mode procedural generation distance appears to be fairly close so lots of stuff "popping" in including the landscape

Conclusion: Excellent for an alpha/early access with lots of features implemented and working well. Shows extreme amounts of promise/potential as long as devs keep working hard at it. Worth the $15 I dropped on it while it was on sale for sure
hoursPlayed: try the demo on the dev website and if crafting/sandbox/survival games are your thing this is DEFINITELY a game for you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A true Indie gem, I got on the Planet Explorer boat back when the game first showed on Kickstarter. Since then many updates have come to the game. They have delivered so far most of thier kickstarter promises and intend to furfill, in the future upcoming updates, more material that seperates PE from other sandbox games.

+Frequent updates
+Quick bug fixes
+3D sandbox with unlimited potential
+Amazing artistic creativity in NPC (wildlife) and a flowing envirement.
+In game creation system ( A tool which will allow you to design your own weapons, vehicles, aircraft, and boats)
+Inexpensive You cannot go wrong with the price for a sandbox

- Sound (basically simple animal sounds and player noises.) In order to better encompass the player in the game a more diverse array of sounds would be great.
- AI is almost aweful, with all the NPC's in this game upgrading the AI is peramount to having a fluid game. Too often are NPC followers  stuck in a ditch or animals frozen with utter stupidity.
- Camara, this has been updated recently however it seems to still be an issue with me while I am mining/tunneling.

Above all, PE is a well-rounded game that deserves more attention. It has a refreshing atmosphere that indeed implores you to explore. I would recommend!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n(First off I appologize for my poor grammer im not very smart)...(30+hours before steam release)..The key aspect of this is Early acess. We all know what it is. A game thats not quite finished but the devs are selling it at its current state to have more money to improve, and/or speed up the devolopment process. That being said planet explorers is completley playable, and enjoyable in its current state. The most appealing aspect is the sandbox gameplay, being able to mine resourses and dynamicly build almost anything you can imagine ( buildings, swords, guns, land and air vehicles. How well you build it will determine how well it works). the terrain deformation is incredibal, I always get a little giddy when digging a tunnel underground. the randomly generated worlds are beautifull, and almost every part of it can be gathered as resources. all in all it is an awsome game. yes a little buggy (early acess) but well worth playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been looking for a Voxel game like this for a long long time. There is much much more in this game then you see in the pictures and videos above.

Let me tell you about this game from start to finish of my entire experience. I only bought this game this morning so this should be short right? Its only been like 17 hours right?... Oh wait, I have around 17 hours play time!

I logged out just a few moments ago for the first time... but I am getting way ahead of myself.

I had been browsing Steam and other various places to buy games that sell games like Planet Explorers, as I have been testing out many of these early access type games. I have been working on many different things in many different games in order to find a game to suit my craving for the ultimate gaming experience.

I decided to test out this game this weekend as I had a little extra money this weekend and it has been a game that I have been doing my home work on over the past few weeks.

After getting into the game and checking out some of the basic things and getting addicted, my friend logs in and I talk to him about the game and he decides to get it.  Now logging out of the Story mode single player (awesome single player story line btw I Highly recommend playing through it, although I have not done the entire story line I have several hours into it and it is pretty neat) and starting up our own server hosted on my buddies computer. His brother gets online as well and buys the game as we tell him its awesome and the 3 of us romp around for several hours till one of them has to work. I have to day off so I get swept away into Planet Explorers and can't stop playing it... its now 3am and I have been online playing this game since around the time I bought it at like 11am... I have to work, but first I have to sleep. I can't wait to learn more about this awesome game and update this further, but already I am sure that this is an awesome game indeed!


********************************************************NOTE TO DEVS************************************************

If any Devs happen to read this, here are some suggestions that would more then likely make this game one of the all time greatest games. Here are just a few things that I personally think if added (if possible) would blow this game further into awesomeness!


**Main Update**

- Add Space!!!! This is Planet Explorers, we should be able to explore other planets. Give us the ability to build vehicles that have the ability to get into orbit and then give us visability of other planets that we can fly too.

**Inside Main Space Update**
-Different Planets- mean diffrenet content, with what you already have now I am sure coming up with 5-10 differnt planet combinations would take a lot of work but would also be do able.... I think...!
-Space Travel- I don't want to build some machine that puts me onto another planet, I want to be able to physically launch off of the current planet and go find another one.
-Different Level Planets- Different types of monsters, elements, ratio of gravity, rarity of resources, hazard terrain, and much much much more. The possibilities are endless with how many different planets you could create!
-Help with thought and design- You know you have an awesome game here, so lets give access to those who want to help. Let people help you by allowing us to design our own content! Give Devs and programmers what they need to make modifications that you can install to the main game. I mean you are still in Early Access right? What if you released a prebeta version that had the above and below modifications?


**Quick Updates**

(Bugs) -Combat is a little off scale and glitchy

(Content)
- Could you give us some more building materials? Or give us more creative ability? We can do a lot already, but the more we have access to the more ideas we will come up with. Not complaining about what we already have but here are a few ideas of what I would like to see.
More Engines
Jets
Space Rocket Materials
Rocket Materials (BIG ONES!)
Solar Energy Capabilities (I mean we should have this I think if we have the ability to travel to other planets)
Space Travel
Voxel Space (Make space FUN!)
Aliens! (The UFO currently in game is kinda cool but also kinda boring, could beef it up with little aliens that jump out of it or something haha who knows.)
Planes! We can build helicopters but no planes :( We have no jet engines.
Astroids, we have a thermosphere so we don't have astroids slamming into our cities very often but... on other planets... who knows what might happen? Maybe have some with new minerals, or ores...?
Crash Landings-Who knows who else is out there, or if they are even human! Obviously we are not alone as their are plenty of other alien creatures on this one single planet already.... Would be cool to have random things hit planets you are on.
Multiple Planets
Astroids in Space
Stars
Moons
Planet Moons/Astroid Belts/Rings
More Ocean, well anything.... just more Ocean stuff. There isn't anything there atm.


There is so much this game could be yet so much that it already is.

Thank you devs if you read this, and hope to hear from you soon.
********************************************************************************






Other then what I have already said this game is super awesome and everything I expected and then more times 100. If you are looking for endless fun pick up this game while it is in Early Access as $25 is absolutely work it in every way.

-Lifemaul

Early Access Review

In terms of open world, sandbox, voxel games and the sort, this game comes highly reccomended for me. The production team has listed their plans as well as their current features clearly, and they have followed through with them in game. They're alpha is already Very playable and enjoyable. The multiplayer is a breeze to set up. The atmosphere is amazing.

After Starforge, I was really hesitant to buy any Early Access Game, no matter how awesome it looked. They oversold their game, and sorely underdelivered their product. Planet Explorers did not do that, and for that, I give this game, as well as it's creators, great respect and high reccomendation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GREAT!!!

So i've played Planet Explorers for about a week now and honestly, i haven't fallen in love with a game like this since Minecraft first came out! Planet Explorers is one of the most emensive and awe-inspiring games i've played in a long time. with a unique building system, interesting story line, and even the ability to bring your own creations to life within the actual game! Planet Explorers REALLY knocks it out of the park!!! however the game does have its cons, things like bugs, glitches, and a few things that need to be tweeked for the gamers experience. I ask you to have an open mind however, as the game is still in its Alpha phase, Planet Explorers has A LOT going for it, and from what ive seen has the potential to posibly be as big as minecraft, bigger perhaps!

This game is addicting. It is very similar to Minecraft (just to throw a reference point out there), but is so much more than that.
The crafting system is simple enough, but the building system (for making your own things) can be quite complex and difficult.
It does not hold your hand, in fact it kind of throws you into it. It does have a questline that help explain things and give you guides on how to do things, but you can run into things you are not prepared for at all.

The graphics are a little low-end, even when running on the Fantatsic" setting. I hope they get revamped before final release

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlanet Explorers has come a long way from its Kickstarter days. Comparing it to Minecraft, as is inevitable with a voxel-based sandbox game, Planet Explorers offers a far greater range of user-created content from weapons to structures, and it actually has a story! If you're looking for a survival experience without all the usual horror aspects, and don't mind a Nintendo-hard difficulty spike midway through the current story, Planet Explorers is a wonderful sci-fi-fantasy romp that can only be stopped by Firebears. Seriously... Fire. Bears.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlanet Explorers has come a long way from its Kickstarter days. Comparing it to Minecraft, as is inevitable with a voxel-based sandbox game, Planet Explorers offers a far greater range of user-created content from weapons to structures, and it actually has a story! If you're looking for a survival experience without all the usual horror aspects, and don't mind a Nintendo-hard difficulty spike midway through the current story, Planet Explorers is a wonderful sci-fi-fantasy romp that can only be stopped by Firebears. Seriously... Fire. Bears.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will make this review the most fair I can for people considering to buy this game:

This game is very similiar in mechanics of other games such as Starbound and Minecraft but with it's own style. The game is still in early Alpha but with the new update I can see that this developer is providing good updates. What makes the game fun is the ability to create, fight and explore in a procedurally created enviroment. I really like the ability of allowing players to create their own custom weapons, allowing lots of creativity. Some of the ISO's (files that save the design of the custom gun or vehicle) people have created are absurdly cool (recreated vehicles of famous movies). I haven't tried multiplayer but I can see how much fun that will be by allowing games such as free for all or capture the fort, or survival (agaist other players or a creature siege). A lot is still a work in progress however. I can tell the developers are working more on the game engine mechanics. Other things such as more character custimization, more eyecandy,  is for later updates. I will try to list some notable qualities currently in the recent build:

- Has some buffers regarding Health and Stamina
- Full open creation of guns and vehicles (cars, helicopters, and now includes making boats and a monorail)
- Many recipes to create objects in game (materials to create items such as weapons, food, certain resources, etc)
- You have to search your resources (esp ores). Don't expect to dig randomly to find ores. Use your scanner to locate ore deposits.
- You can farm your own crops.
- Fast travel is allowed (starting colony only at the moment though)
- Very large maps (huge in my opinion) and you can also mark and label locations on map.
- Animal AI is getting better (pack hunting and herding). It's like you are on Pandora (from Avatar) but you are poaching every living animal and you use their meat as currency (At the moment...it might change, I am speculating) to buy items and resources if you don't wish to create everything yourself.
- You can have NPC followers and create your own base and assign them jobs. This is still a work in progress however, IDK how much progress  they made in version A.08

Remember that this is an EARLY ACCESS GAME! Saves can be compromised when updating the game, glitches still exist, the are many areas left to finish. The game itself at its current build is very enjoyable though. So far it hasn't crashed on me yet or have encountered any glitches or game breaking bugs.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brilliant game. Honestly, the whole colony thing isn't the best part. It's the exploration, challenges, and building. I haven't played multiplayer yet, though. The story isn't done yet, but what is in, is great. The only thing that sucks about it is waiting (Walking Dead Telltale game, anyone?) There are a couple bugs, but not game breaking, some useful in a non-cheaty way (Usually.)
The graphics of the character are interesting, not my favorite, but I could care less.

Bad stuff:
Crashes once every 1-2 hour(s). Not the normal crash though, it freezes, and if you tab out you see a dialog box. The other one is an ingame message with an error. It usually saves often though, so you shouldn't lose much, if anything at all. The ingame error seems harmless, I just save and reload my game. If your game crashes in the launcher, try changing the drivers under options, I was using a nonexistent one for some reason.

*EDIT: As of writing this, I have 20 hours played. 20 Hours in a story that doesn't appear to be even close to finished is great, and I can't wait for more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many things to like: lots of freedom, digging, very open world, quests, an engaging plot, building with both prefab and various blocks.
Similarly crafting includes both classic recipe and freeform voxel-oriented forms, with more items being possible to craft freeform over time, as the devs find balanced rules for them.
As with other early access games performance can be a bit sketchy in certain poorly optimized cases, but the game is entirely playable on the reccomended hardware.
A few bugs, but this is not unexpected for early access.
Because the game uses a bit more aggressive gpu computation, it will appreciate a flaky gpu less than some lucky games. This is likely to remain the case, and even become true of more other games as time passes anyway, though. :p

Personally, I'd prefer if the design editor felt more integrated with the game - right now it feels much more like a meta process which messes with one's feel of existing in the world a bit. not sure how much this can be improved, given that the editor needs to be usable from *outside* of play as well. I hope they find some sweet compromises, though. :)

Overall I quite enjoyed the game in it's current state, and I look forward to playing it more as development progresses, and again whenever it releases.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you love Minecraft, you will love this game. To me, it is what Minecraft could have been. If you are an artistic person, you can create so much more than just buildings made of cubes in this game, you can create your own weapons and vehicles as well.

The ISO Editor, the thing you use to create new items and structures, is very flexible and powerful, I would say it is an easier to use version of Maya, with obviously less features, but still really close to a full 3D Modeling tool.

If you aren't as artistic (like me) there is plenty to do, the mining and combat systems are extremely natural feeling, when you swing your pick, you remove a section of land in a non cube shape, better picks mine faster and a larger area. You can dig an actual moat around your fortress if you so desire.

All in all, I would highly recommend this game to any and all fans of Open World Sandbox/Survival.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With 20hrs under the belt I can safely say that this game is fantastic.  There is so much to do and so much life to the game.  I will break it down by features.
Graphics:
The graphics are great.  There isn't as much control over what features pertaining to graphics are used but enough to make sure your system can run it properly.  At full quality it looks stunning.  Light permeating through tree leaves, a nice not-over-done bloom effect, AA, it all works great and runs smooth.  Very pleasing to the eyes.  The voxel engine handles very well and even with an older video card, the game handles it all very well and even displays very far into the distance (im using a nvidia 560ti).    The weather is handled very nice and looks good.  Night time is actual night time.  You can hardly see at pitch black and need a torch or light.

Characters:
It is great that they allow you to create your own custom character like sims or elderscrolls games.  The NPCs are active but not to the extent of say skyrim where they have jobs.  They sort of just stand around and walk here and there. You can talk to them and get a lot of story background which is great.  You can even enlist some of them to fight beside you and you can equip them with armor and weapons and whatnot.  The mercenaries have their own set of special skills too.  Some are great with swords and others with guns and so on.  Adds nicely to who you choose to follow you.  I like that the mercenaries reappear beside you when you get too far from them.

Story:
Great story line.  Makes you want to learn more and more about what is going on.  This coming from a guy that usually is not interested in story.  I found myself wanting to know what happened.  That doesn't happen often at all.

Sound/music:
The sound was good.  The music adjusted appropriately depending on where you were and whether or not you were in the area of a hostile enemy. It was a little glitchy but I've read they are fixing that.  Sound effects fit weapons and whatnot.  It could use more attention to vehicles and sounds but overall still good.

Quests:
The quests are your run of the mill quests.  They are good and add to the the story.  They don't always feel quite at all like a grind.  Some can be, but that is normal it seems.  Other quests are more detailed.  I will say there are some bad bugs with some of the quests that require a npc to follow you.  That npc is prone to get stuck at a tree or rock and unlike the mercs that you hire, the quest npcs don't reappear at your side if you move too far away.  I have found that if you have a quest npc with you, if you bring out a vehicle and get in it, the npc will rellocate to your vehicle which is an unintended fix.  This leads to problems early game especially when you are travelling long distances.  When you have quest npcs with you, you can't fast travel.  If they get unexpectedly stuck in a tree you have to travel all the way back to retreive them.  This can be frustrating. There are some quests that you receive early in the game that won't be completed until later.  Many have had problems with this.  I imagine it will be fixed in later versions given this game is only early access.  SOme quests are a little buggy but that is mostly due to the fact that npcs end up getting stuck in random places.  There was one quest involving two npcs and I couldn't complete the quest because one of the npcs randomly got stuck in a mountain side and I couldn't get him down until I dug out the mountain side.

Building:
The game contains a lot of building which is great.  Kind of like minecraft.  You can make your own weapons and vehicles and whatnot.  You require schematics to build things and sometimes require to build one thing in order to build another.  It doesn't get overly complicated though.  The difficulty of the build is often representative of the usefulness of what you are building.  For instance, you can't just easily build a helicopter.  It requires you build a cockpick, rotors, engines, energy cells, etc.  It is a very intuitive building system that takes a little time to get use to but once you are it is very easy to use.  There is a lot of fun to be had.  A lot of creativity that can be used.  I will say the game could do better at helping you understand the proper needs of a vehicle.  I made a dune-buggy type car and I had all the pieces but in game I got this red text at the bottom that told me the car is overpowered or something.  It never really told me why it was overpowered or how to fix it.  The car still worked fine as it was.

Enemies:
There are a lot of animals and enemies in the game.  Many of the animals are docile until you attack them which is nice.  Some of the animals are hostile from the start and it is fun and interesting to see which animals will attack on site and which animals will run right beside you.  The enemies are dangerous too.  Some prefer to sit back and snipe you.  Others will come slinging swords and whatnot.  Some will even mount turrets and will sling rockets and bullets at your face.  The animals and enemies come in all shapes and sizes and the size of the mob usually indicates how dangerous they are.  There are a few points where you fight some extremely large enemies and they can prove quite hard to defeat.  I will say the ranged mobs seem a lot more easy to conquer given they can be dodged easily.

Overall:
Wonderful game with a ton of potential.  It already has a great deal built into and most of what will probably come from later versions is just more content.  I hope they fix some of the not-so-obvious bugs mentioned above (I am sure they will).  Creating your own camp and playing tower defense was really fun.  Being able to craft cars and helicopters and then drive them around was extremely fun.  The game does a great job easing you into the features and concepts of the game.  Very fun and leaves you wanting more (it is in alpha so that is to be expected).  I look forward to future updates and highly recommend you buying this game now if you enjoy rpg and open world sandbox games like terraria and minecraft.  There is a lot of replayability built into the game and right now about 20hrs worth of straight story line with some random quests thrown in.  It is a very balanced game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I guess now would be a good time to write a review though I have never done one before.

Planet Explorers I feel reminds me most of an old mmo called Star Wars Galaxies. This game combines house building, vehicle building, armor crafting, weapon crafting, and technology. As well as the normal monster huting and looting, though it is unlike you will find a weapon on a random creature.

This game does have its bugs as is seen when a creature some how manages to float up a tree without moving, but hey... its alpha. The combat is fun though a bit repeatitive on the actions, same swinging animation. But to be honest the game is very fun, and a different trend then the MMO that we are used to. The graphics may fall short but this does not mean that the sceen is any less beautiful. The landscape is vast and its quite daunting to consider how long it will take to explore all of it... and thats just for the main story line.

Now I believe something I should touch base on is the crafting system. As I mentioned very indepth but a bit hard to understand first off. Items you need to make you first must get the recipe from mobs or NPC's. After that you then have to find the resources and craft the specific item which is normal enough. But when you look to create a vehicle you must make sure to have the specific items your going to use when crafting it in your editor.

The mining, herb picking, and diging is all very fluent and easy to get the hang of. I would highly recommend this game if you are looking for something to keep you interested while waiting for the next big mmo. I personally have not tried the multiplayer yet, but from what I understand it does work... and to be honest whats better then exploring a massive span of land with some friends.

I look forward to the future updates this game offers, and I hope many of you enjoy this game as much as I do.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Personally, and professionally, I'd wait till this game is no longer Early Access. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game and shows a ton of potential. Using Voxels beyond what Minecraft has done is AWESOME, and the graphics, gameplay, combat, feel natural.

With that said however, it needs a bit more polish, it's a tad glitchy, even if most of the game stoppers have been killed. There's the little bugs, the annoying, 'I was in a cave digging rock and poof! I'm outside!' or 'why is that ten ton beast on top of a tree 1/5 his size?' minor grammer bugs need work, dialog voices need better volume as you can't hear them... at all. More things need added, ect ect ect.

Again, whats there is great, what can be is better, but right now... wait to buy. This will be my official review (FOR NOW), it's a great concept, and great game play, but it needs a wee bit more time for some polish. If you can ignore the 'minor issues', however, buy this game right away. Otherwise, wait, trust me, add this to your wish list, in 6 to 8 months, buy it then, it'll be worth the wait.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Currently there are game breaking bugs and you need a pretty beastly machine to even run the game at medium settings.

As of now I've played Planet Explorers since it was made available to play off and on. This is my review as of version a0.87.

Earlier more stable versions allowed me to play with no problems while runing into rare bugs in story mode. I was also able to play with friends in multiplayer mode with little issues though lack of content made it boring at the time.

This latest version seems to have implemented game-breaking story mod bugs as well as many performance decreasing issues that have been left unattended to. It seems Pathea takes a long time to release patches and fix issues. But the patches of content they release are amazing compared to other games, however spread very far apart making the patches not so great.

I am currently NOT going to recommend the game at this time as Multiplayer can end up boring and Story Mode (Single Player) seems to have a fair share of issues and game-breaking bugs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On the surface Planet Explorers seems like a quick cash-in on the Crafting/Exploration genre, which is not to imply it doesn't succeed at what it intends to do. While still in Early Access this title performs very well on both fronts, and should not be dismissed for the bugs/flaws currently in-game.  The attempt at exploration Planet Explorers makes is impressive, and although the graphics may be a little dated, the scenery can be downright beautiful at times.  Even with a map as vast as the one in Planet Explorers moving forward is not always the best option, with vast cave networks easily discovered using you Handheld PC, you won't have to venture far to discover the unknown.  One flaw that currently is plaguing this title is the draw distance, and the rate at which the landscape appears, while easily written off as an Early Access issue, it is one that will need to be addressed before official release.

Crafting in Planet Explorers can feel like the usual fanfare, resource tiers(wood, rock, copper, iron, etc), but the Creations Editor is where the crafting in this title moves beyond what I've encountered so far in my gaming experience. Yes, other games have had content creation, map editors, etc, but Planet Explorers brings it right to the forefront of its systems.  While the Creations Editor(a more accurate name would be Blueprint Editor) can seem daunting and unwieldy, spending time learning it's nuances will quickly show you just how robust this tool can be.  I have had a blast buidling new vehicles and testing them in Build Mode to see how well they perform, and the experience brings me back to my childhood playing with legos.

While Planet Explorers is on the right path towards what, in my eyes, is the next evolution of the Crafting/Exploration genre, it is not without it's bugs. I previously mentioned the draw distance, which is an issue for immersion, but also for traversing the map in aircrafts, or other very fast moving vehicles. While travelling around the map you will have trees, animals, mountains, and more appear in front of you, often leading to emergency meneuvers.  With the robust Creation Editor, and Steam Workshop support this title has the potential to develop a large following, and create many memorable moments.  Other bugs do occur, and not all game elements are currently implemented, but I feel with our support this could be a title to throw up on the board with Minecraft, and if all the kinks are worked out it will surpass it in what it does.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLikely the best voxel sandbox game to come out to date, Planet Explorers gives the player unprecidented freedom to design weapons, vehicles, and buildings; voxel by voxel. Lush environments, a great story line, active ecology, and the ability to harvest from almost anything you can see on screen make this the most compelling sandbox game currently available. As of this writing; there are a few technical issues, none of which are show stoppers (indeed I have only had one crash ever) and most of the bugs are cosmetic in nature. Not bad for a game in early alpha. This title shows great promise as a freeform Adventure RPG and creative sandbox experience. I'm hooked and impatiently awaiting a0.76!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I reaaally want to love this game.  I really do, I've had a ton of fun playing when we'd actually manage to get it to work.  Multiplayer needs to be fixed.  It's so frustrating having so many problems with joining or hosting a private game, even with all the correct ports opened.    It's been out for a year, I've had the game for about that long and I honestly haven't seen any improvements whatsoever. I get that it's an Early Access game, I can handle the lags and the bugs... most of them anyway, but the way multiplayer works right now has got to get a complete overhaul.  We shouldn't have to rent out a dedicated server or have some tech wiz come and try to figure out why we can't connect for us.  This limits the playerbase to those who can actually figure it out (or has the means to get help), and with a game as immersive as PE is, it would definitely be worth the change.  It sucks, I mean I was just on and there were only 7 or 8 people total ingame throughout all 8 pages of listed servers.  While I appreciate the updates, I really think that I won't be touching the game until multiplayer is fixed, if that ever even happens.

That being said, I'm totally willing to change my review to positive if something huge changes.  Please stop fixing bugs and focus on changing the way multiplayer connectivity works.  It shouldn't be an issue if you were ever planning on PE players to enjoy the game.

Early Access Review

Personally, and professionally, I'd wait till this game is no longer Early Access. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game and shows a ton of potential. Using Voxels beyond what Minecraft has done is AWESOME, and the graphics, gameplay, combat, feel natural.

With that said however, it needs a bit more polish, it's a tad glitchy, even if most of the game stoppers have been killed. There's the little bugs, the annoying, 'I was in a cave digging rock and poof! I'm outside!' or 'why is that ten ton beast on top of a tree 1/5 his size?' minor grammer bugs need work, dialog voices need better volume as you can't hear them... at all. More things need added, ect ect ect.

Again, whats there is great, what can be is better, but right now... wait to buy. This will be my official review (FOR NOW), it's a great concept, and great game play, but it needs a wee bit more time for some polish. If you can ignore the 'minor issues', however, buy this game right away. Otherwise, wait, trust me, add this to your wish list, in 6 to 8 months, buy it then, it'll be worth the wait.
