reviewText:
Early Access Review

Has a few bugs, but still an amazing game. It *is* still early access, but generally you won't know.
8.5/10
I bought this last year (I think), and the interface was a bit iffy. Collecting parts was near impossible and I thought I was just doing it wrong. The new version's UI works just as I'd expect it to (phew, I'm not crazy!).
The game is one off the newfandangled voxel based games that are popping up everywhere. You mine, dig, shoot, stab and  cut (animals, plants and the ground) to get materials and use them to make inventory items like guns, healing potions, etc. All the dirt that you mined up? Well, it seems you can use that to build structures a la minecraft.
There is also customization of things you build, so you can pretty much build whatever you want. I haven't really played with that yet, the screen scared me since it's too powerful, but I hear it's pretty cool.
There is a main mission that you should really play to get the hang of things, and the devs seem to put out frequent updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a wonderful game and fulfilled all my expectations.  I highly recommend it, because as much fun as I've had with it now, it's only going to get better as the game comes closer and closer to exiting early access.  There are still some bugs to work out, but I wouldn't say they're a major hindrance to enjoying Planet Explorers.

I played several hours of the campaign and a bit of the exploration mode.  The mining, crafting, gathering and cooking systems are very solid.  The 3D resource scanner system takes a lot of the guess work out of things, which is very welcome, and the inventory system isn't oppressive with encumberance or backpack limitations.  Upgrading gear between schematics and resource quality was very rewarding and interesting - eventually taking huge chunks of a mountain out at a time felt really good after plinking away at it with a low tier copper pickaxe.

The combat has a lot of flexibility and is entirely gear dependent, and if you have the right minerals, you have the best gear.  The follower systems ensures very good balance for most situations.  Multiplayer was a blast, and buildin my own settement was very rewarding.  As was building my own vehicle from a blueprint starting with no template, only key parts.

The game's seeds are not impossibly large, and have a lot going on to the point where you'll never have to trudge for a long distance totally bored, unless you want to just to explore.  Very interesting wildlife designs and behaviors, lots of predator/prey ambient stuff going on that you can watch.  The giant antagonists are rightfully dangerous and intimidating, very challenging but not impossible to overcome with a solid team.

I very much enjoy this game.  If I had to complain, I'd say that I wish there was more to the character customization, and some of the storyline quests have some annoying bugs, mostly relating to friendly AI behavior.  The game can be gorgeous in places, but only if you ignore some of the low res, constantly repeating ground textures.

Regardless, I still highly recommend Planet Explorers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off: This game is very alpha. There's a reason it's early access. It's improving, but don't expect a complete, polished game.

On the surface this just looks like yet another ripoff of Minecraft, although in this case with gorgeous graphics. It's not. It takes a whole different angle on building things, giving the player a lot of freedom to shape things exactly how they want—if they're willing to take the time to learn the still-rather-clunky UI. You can build a nice house, but you can also build your own sword, gun, vehicle and various other things. It takes the concept of crafting beyond a preset list of things and almost brings CAD into a game. Extremely unique, and while I can't promise everyone will like it, if anything in my review sounded interesting, it might be worth a try.

This game is not for every one. You've got to be patient. It's an alpha and by that I mean a real alpha. Not those comercial ones you can see every where. It's far from finished and has been in developement for a long time : the team is small. But they d'ont give up their game like so many and they push on, polishing it. Trust me when I tell you that this game once finished will be great. For the moment there are lots of flaws, clunkyness and a few bugs. But they keep improving. This is one of those game where you should keep an eye on if you can't play alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ill start with what I liked about the game:
The single player is fairly fun, it has quests and the like. Crafting system is very basic and the UI is easy to understand. Graphics are nothing to write home about but are okay and playable in my opinion. The custom content creator is VERY cool which you can make custom 3D vehicles and weapons after getting used to it for about 10 minutes. The content you made can be seen in-game right after you make it (after you purchase it and materials). Its also a voxel game which means the mining and everything is in 3D as opposed to minecraft where its all blocks. Combat can also be fun against certain mobs and large boss monsters. The vehicles and equipment can be fun to use like the jetpack + glider.


Why I don't recommend it:
First of all the game has been in development for about 3 years now and I still feel like its VERY unfinnished. Most of my complaint is the multiplayer. The lobby is REALLY buggy and attempting to connect to friends can be a pain. Me and my friends played it for about 25 or so hours (steam says only 10 because it disables after you close the launcher) and we pretty much did all that you can do in the game and quickly got bored.
Building structures is very lame and unrewarding as there is practically no actual use for them other than aesthetics (they also look terrible). It also feels very awkward to build and you don't get much choice in materials and objects to use.

The survival element is mostly just fighting off monsters. Which until you can afford to buy weapons, is almost impossible. You also have NO reason to craft items as you can BUY everything via in-game shop which after you just mine random ores and sell it you can buy anything you want fairly quickly, you get end-game content in under an hour if you wanted.

I feel like the game is VERY lackluster in content and will only keep you entertained for 30 hours at most before you get bored of it. They say they will release the game sometime in 2014 and if they do at this state then that means this game is a ripoff. There was also plenty of bugs but because it is early access I won't have that as a reason for my unrecommendation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was really enthusiastic about this game at first. Now I'm not so sure. There are a lot more sandbox survival games coming out that have a lot of the same features that I'd like to try out. I feel like Planet Explorers has used a lot of their resources on the wrong things, maybe?

I´ve also had problems with the game crashing on load on both my Macbook Pro and my brand new Digital Storm gaming PC running Windows 8. There are a lot of stability problems that have not been improved in the year since I first got the game.

In any case, it's not worth $25, especially for early access. (Please get your voice actors back to finish their lines.) If it were only $15 I'd definitely say go for it. But check out a Let's Play on YouTube to decide for sure for yourself. Maybe you should try Subnautica instead.

I´m going to hold out until the next UI update, but if some of the weird quirks don´t get fixed, I´m giving up.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game in 2014 early in its development because I thought it had potential, played it a bit and decided to leave it on the shelf for later. Last week I started a new game to see how things where going and it got me hooked! As it is now the single player story (which is well conceived and interesting btw) and the ISO editor (you can design vehicles, submarines, helicopters, boats, guns, armor, etc) are worth dozens of hours of fun. Its a sort of modern futuristic minecraft with a more elegant and advanced crafting system and UI that I very much enjoy. Highly recommended, can't wait for the final version.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As it stands right now, the game is what I'd call early proof-of-concept. It's playable to a degree, but gets old very quickly. The game's UI needs some serious flow tweaks - right now, even with the tutorial system in place, the UI doesn't provide enough information to get a player going. Luckily, you can skip over most of the broken bits. Once you're on the 'planet', there's an handful of quests that you can do, but the flow quickly rears its ugly head and the 'game' is more a set of chores.

Perhaps in 5 years time, the game will be closer to what the developer envisioned. As for now, however, it will sit in my game library until it gets beyond a POC.
voteText: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is amazing. At first, it just seems like a nice solo survival game, but then it morphs into a game where you're creating your own equipment voxel-by-voxel (you can use others' creations if you don't want to design it yourself), building a colony, and managing a group of survivors. In single player, there's a campaign that is well written and interesting. Just with what's in the game now I can highly recommend it. I've played 80 hours up to this point, and I can easily say it's one of my best Early Access experiences. Development speed is on the slow end of the spectrum, but steady. Each release is sizeable, which makes for an interesting replay. Also, the music is fantastic. Seriously.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good game, a bit too grindy for me, but I have supported this since it was first added to steam. Each time I open this game I am delightfully surprised with the new content and interest creatures I find.

The game is very complicated and feels a lot like an MMO, resources are usually quite rare, and bullets are even harder to come by, which makes melee combat the most used for me. However most of the aliens on this planet can kill you in 1 or 2 hits. So melee combat is usually a bad idea.

To this day I still don't know how to actually make/import a vehicle into my game, I have looked up tutorials but there are so many buttons it is very overwhelming. Overall this game has always been an awesome idea when I look at it, but when I play it I find myself lost.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sick and tired of Early Access games full of hype and potential but havent been updated in months?
Planet Explorers is one of the best open world sandbox games currently in Early Access!  the devs have continued to update the game with patches that come out on a monthly basis if not more!  The Devs also maintain a constant stream of information flowing to the public in regards to the progress and status of the the next updates.

The game itself has a very powerfull voxel creation system.  it allows you to create any type of weapon, vehicle or structure!

The game is set on an alien planet where your vessel is forced to make an emergency landing, the story line takes deeper into the world as well as deeper into a political fiasco that places the survivors at risk of a civil war.

this game is worth far more then its current price and is well worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A0.95 Review

I've played almost all story mode and I like what I see from the story so far.

Combat:  You can't just slug it out with critters.  Dodge and kite and you'll be fine.
Also watch the skies in the grassland areas, the flying predators will try to snack on you.

Colony Building:  Absolutely love this part of the game.  I'm a bit of a base building fanatic and setting up a self sustaining cabe is right up my alley.

Creation System for designing your own....  well almost everything.  You can design weapons and vehicles from scratch here.  The interface isn't very intuitive and I can't make stuff look good at all, but lots of people upload the specs of some pretty incredible creations.
Wouldn't mind seeing some Dev-made already ingame premades for the vehicles though.
1-2 of each basic type would do (motorbike, landrover, vertical-take-off-landing craft, boats, etc.)

It's still in Alpha, but I can see a huge amount of promise here.  Especially looking forward towards multiplayer story mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really liked this game in the beginning, played about 17 hrs worth.  Decided to reinstall recently and see how it is coming along,  but after recent patches the game has become frustrating to play for two reasons:

Keybinds- Certain keys can no longer be changed, this is a big issue as I use EDSF instead of WSAD.  Unfortunately E is Interact and can't be changed.  Be aware you may not be able to change keybinds to what you want.

Hitching- I can run the game in Fantastic setting with 60-100 fps but every minute or two I get this half a second hitch where the screen sorta freezes.

My current suggestion is wait longer before getting this game.  If the dev team can correct the keybind and hitching issue I'd love to give the game a try again.  They have added a lot of really nice elements to the game, I just find it unplayable in the current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers is certainly one of the best games in Early Access. There are some bugs and a lack of polish, but overall a great buy.

Pros   Very full featured--By this, I mean it delivers all its core game mechanics with depth. Trading works. Crafting works. Crafting is multi-tiered. Crafting the items isn't hard to mess up. But the ability to build your vehicles and items with such minute detail is incredible and really no bugs to speak of here.
The storyline--Typically I don't care much for the story of a game. This one had me reloading saves if I missed anything. I loved the story up to where they have it.
Building your own colony--And you get to populate it as well, assign jobs. Essentially micromanage the thing if you wish.
You get out of it what you put into it--This game answers the call of your desires. Strategy? Check. Action? Check. Survival? Check. Exploration? Absolutely.
The detail--This goes hand in hand with the next bullet point. The creators of the game took great care to make everything in the world make sense. The NPCs are exploring the planet and explain why the planet is the way it is when you land there.
Exploration--It is a joy to just fly around and see the sights and discover new things. The game has loads of content.
Cons   Bugs--There are game breaking bugs. I'm not sure if I finished the storyline up to where it was built or if my quests just bugged out. This game is in alpha. And I can assure you that the majority of the bugs I encountered that left a bad taste in my mouth dealt with the their questing system. There were points where I ran out of memory (I'm running full settings on a great PC). No big deal, reload an autosave. But the questing bugs caused me to lose hours. I request that there be some console mode like Skyrim to assist players in self-help remedial measures when it comes to questing bugs.
Lack of Polish--I include this because every aspect of the game can use more polish. Polish is the stuff that makes a B+ into an A. And the developers should hold off on this aspect. The game does not need polish in this state. It is in Early Access.
END OF LIST (for now)
I mean that. These are the only cons to me. It plays like a finished game short of the questing bugs. I can excuse this of course. It is in Alpha. And the lack of polish is not a con to me, but I leave it there for a discriminating gamer.

Story mode is not where it ends. I wanted to put Adventure Mode in Pros, but because of it being more or less an afterthought, I felt that Adventure Mode could not be justified in the Pro category. Adventure Mode is basically playing a randomized map with all features except the main story. But it needs much more work. But I am encouraged that it is there in the first place and am eager to see the developers flesh out the features of the adventure mode. Therefore, I do not think it qualifies as a Con I would prefer not being given everything (scanner updates and all scripts in the beginning of the Adventure Mode). Instead, I would like this to be an option that I could elect.

A previous reviewer gave a thumbs down in saying that the project was so immense that it would never be completed. Gamers have a vote in this. We vote with our wallets and our recommendations. I have done both, and encourage you to purchase this game and play some of it. It is expensive for early access, but the content it delivers is well beyond its price. And then please, when you discover this game's merits, support the devs. Endorse this game that so richly deserves recognition.

But the ability to build your vehicles and items with such minute detail is incredible and really no bugs to speak of here.
The storyline--Typically I don't care much for the story of a game. This one had me reloading saves if I missed anything. I loved the story up to where they have it.
Building your own colony--And you get to populate it as well, assign jobs. Essentially micromanage the thing if you wish.
You get out of it what you put into it--This game answers the call of your desires. Strategy? Check. Action? Check. Survival? Check. Exploration? Absolutely.
The detail--This goes hand in hand with the next bullet point. The creators of the game took great care to make everything in the world make sense. The NPCs are exploring the planet and explain why the planet is the way it is when you land there.
Exploration--It is a joy to just fly around and see the sights and discover new things. The game has loads of content.
Cons   Bugs--There are game breaking bugs. I'm not sure if I finished the storyline up to where it was built or if my quests just bugged out. This game is in alpha. And I can assure you that the majority of the bugs I encountered that left a bad taste in my mouth dealt with the their questing system. There were points where I ran out of memory (I'm running full settings on a great PC). No big deal, reload an autosave. But the questing bugs caused me to lose hours. I request that there be some console mode like Skyrim to assist players in self-help remedial measures when it comes to questing bugs.
Lack of Polish--I include this because every aspect of the game can use more polish. Polish is the stuff that makes a B+ into an A. And the developers should hold off on this aspect. The game does not need polish in this state. It is in Early Access.
END OF LIST (for now)
I mean that. These are the only cons to me. It plays like a finished game short of the questing bugs. I can excuse this of course. It is in Alpha. And the lack of polish is not a con to me, but I leave it there for a discriminating gamer.

Story mode is not where it ends. I wanted to put Adventure Mode in Pros, but because of it being more or less an afterthought, I felt that Adventure Mode could not be justified in the Pro category. Adventure Mode is basically playing a randomized map with all features except the main story. But it needs much more work. But I am encouraged that it is there in the first place and am eager to see the developers flesh out the features of the adventure mode. Therefore, I do not think it qualifies as a Con I would prefer not being given everything (scanner updates and all scripts in the beginning of the Adventure Mode). Instead, I would like this to be an option that I could elect.

A previous reviewer gave a thumbs down in saying that the project was so immense that it would never be completed. Gamers have a vote in this. We vote with our wallets and our recommendations. I have done both, and encourage you to purchase this game and play some of it. It is expensive for early access, but the content it delivers is well beyond its price. And then please, when you discover this game's merits, support the devs. Endorse this game that so richly deserves recognition.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game definitely has some potential, and I think that by the time it has been released, most of my issues with it will be fixed. And if they are, I will definitely rewrite this review and recommend it.

So here's why I don't recommend this game at the moment; First, it's an alpha so there's going to be lag and bugs. I expected this and this isn't really a complaint about the game itself, and I'm positive most of it will be fixed but it still made my experience with it worse.

Then there's the combat, the combat is terrible and consists of clicking left click and hoping you won't die. While you're slashing your sword you can actually not even move, so pretty much all strategy is taken away here. The hit detection is broken too, I took damage several times when whatever I was fighting clearly did not hit me. If this game got a combat system similar to the one in Monster Hunter, that would be amazing, though that's probably putting my hopes too high.

The mining isn't very fun either. In games like Minecraft, Terraria or Starbound, mining is awesome because it's very easy and when you see that diamond or whatever you get really excited. In this game, all you do is mine stone and hope you get something good. It's neither fun or exciting, and pretty awkward.

I hope, and think this will be fixed by the time this game is released, and if it is I can see myself playing this a lot, but at the moment I don't feel like I can recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have patience and don't mind waiting for something that will be special, get this game!  I might just buy it for some of my friends anyways!

Random thoughts on the game:

Game has tons of potential, the horrendously slow development time has been a pain in the butt, but at least they've not given up on it!

Compared to the many other voxel games out there, I feel that this one allows you the most creativity and customization, just on a much smaller scale.  You can import your own textures and decals so that alone gives you nearly unlimited design possibilities.

You want to make an exact replica of a WW2 Tommy Gun complete with serial numbers etched into the gun, you can!  You want to make an Apache Longbow on a 1:1 scale?  You can!  You want to make a wooden pirate ship?  You can!

Trying to make a solid glass material, I accidentally made a block that changes color with the time of day, I call it a happy accident!

Downside, no real flying vehicles, the airships may fly"
date: but they still handle like a car and can't even go over many trees.  Fortunately the hit boxes for the larger trees are ignored and you can go through them.\n\nQuests are a little buggy at times
recommended: but I am happy to notice that they are usually fixed as the community points them out and ones that aren't fixxable with a patch usually fix themselves after you save your game and reload it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is making a lot of progress, but it's still a little rough around the edges.  It needs more work in almost all areas, especially the user interface design.  That said, I love the ideas behind this game, and the concept makes a great sandbox game even in its current state.  I hope the devs finish this and turn it into a masterpiece.

The graphics are great, though I wish for better animations and more exciting combat.  Combat is similar to old school RuneScape point-and-click fare, except that you have to move the character with the WASD keys and stay close to the enemy.  You don't have to worry about much in combat other than your weapon and your health.  Animations are also really dry, allowing for very little to actually happen on the screen, outside of menus.  Dialogue is not animated at all, and on that note, dialogue is tiny, at the bottom of the screen, so it's hard to read.

Controls are decent.  WASD keys move, right-click-and-hold to move the camera with the mouse.  Unfortunately, you can't walk backward.  That's not a big deal, but it was slightly annoying during combat.  You can't move and hit at the same time, so it really didn't make much difference.  Most of the game is played with the mouse, utilizing draggable menu panels, but you can set hotkeys for weapons and tools.

Overall, the voxel-based building is a lot of fun, so much fun that it kind of redeems the game's flaws.  Considering it is still in Early Access, I have hope for this game, but it has been in development for a long time, so I won't lie, I'm worried about its future.  That's why I bought a Steam copy.  I'm showing my support.  I wish the devs the best of luck with future improvements.

In honor of full disclosure, I worked for Pathea as an independent web developer for their website back in 2013.  My opinions may be biased in many ways.  I knew about and followed the progress of this game since they put it in a bundle back then.  Working with them allowed me even earlier access to the game, back in the beginning of 2014.  It has been about a year since then, and the game looks a lot more playable now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quick summary at bottom of review.

Review
Planet Explorers is a good game with even greater potential. Yes the game is Early Access and it wont be released/completed for a while yet, but it's certainly worth supporting the developers and watching the game evolve.

In it's current state it is playable, though you'll encounter alot of bugs and such. One of the worst examples is the Adventure Mode randomly generated worlds. You choose 1 of 4 biomes to be your main biome to play in, the others you'll practically never see in game. Not only this but the original spawn point and camp is normally on it's own island surrounded by a large crevice on all sides (imagine Avatar's floating islands, except these are connected to the world vertically). Not too much of a problem, just build a make-shift bridge out of dirt or something. But it does cause alot of annoyance.

Story Mode seem relatively good, though I have barely touched it as it is at this point a long tutorial which you can get the over all feel and mechanics of the game within an hour.

As for custom content, this is where the game shines. You can create a nice variety of items and weapons in game at this time. Here's a quick list of 'functional' things you can create; Swords, Shields, Firearms, Boats, Wheeled Vehicles (any type on land transport), Helicopters and Planes. Now when I say functional I mean things that you can use. You can also create in-animate objects, wether it be a flag or a wall decoration, the option is there.

As for the construction mechanic, it works well. Everything is built with blocks and easy to place with good camera controls, and your buildings don't look blocky at all they are smooth. Though the gathering of these resources is very tedious. Just scan for ores and mine them or just stand in one spot and hold LMB and keep mining. That's it. There is a scanner that can tell you the location of ores in the world within a short radius, but I rarely use it as the most needed ore can be found in stone alot of the time.

Combat is again, tedious. Simpley hold LMB until it dies. That's it. Would be nice if there would be (in the future) a skill system making you more proficient in either melee or ranged, with usable skills so you have to be more active in combat. The problem you will have is in Adventure Mode, any level creature will spawn anywhere. You could spawn near an alien camp, which would mean aliens would always be close to you and until you have good enough loot you will keep dying.

Thing's I'd Like To See
More 'functional' items to create. An example: custom bed or lights.
Better combat with possibility of skills.
Make mining less tedious (no idea how that'd be done though).
Make world generation in Adventure mode contain all biomes.
A variety of pre-built items for those who can't create things too well. Or at least blueprints for them (Just a simple car and plane etc)

Summary
So a quick summary of positive (+) and negative (-) points of the game:

+Custom content, create what you want.
+Choice of 3 game modes (Story, Adventure and Build)
+A good amount of crafting recipes, including armour and utilities such as a jet pack.
+A very well thought out game which i#has so far been exectued really well.

-Story mode (for me) drags on way to long as a long tutorial, didn't even finish it.
-World generation in current build for Adventure Mode is messy. Also limited to one biome in adventure mode.
-Tedious mining and combat.
-Optimisation (expected to have problems as it is Alpha, not game breaking though)

A solid 7/10.

I have about 75 hours total on this game. Many of them were spent playing when i had no internet, so steam didnt record them.

It sucks that the map is limited right now, but im sure with time it will improve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this game because its fun to run around, dig, build, create.  One can experiment with architectural design.  That's enough for me to be satisfied but the game as a story has major problems:

Be prepared to be frustrated with bugs in the story line.  I've played this game on and off for a while, seen it go through quite a few versions.  On an earlier version I was able to play through story mode pretty far, as far as the developers had written.  My saves were erased with an upgrade and given the amount of time I had spent crafting a delightful and luxurious base, I became discouraged.  I tried to restart, to plod through the storyline with its many fetch-type quests but with another upgrade those saves got erased too.  Recently I came back to the game and have been having fun with it again.  Strangely, though, I cannot get very far in the story quests.  They are extremely buggy.  The story quests appear to have actually become quite a bit MORE buggy since the last time I'd played it.  I can't get past the first quest (a critical character has irretrievably disappeared, and was just reading about the second quest having a high likelihood of a massive game ending type bug also.

It is difficult to program games and I respect the hard work.  That being said, I recommend the developers focus on making the core gameplay stable instead of pursuing shiny, new, additional features with each update. I fear/suspect the game has been dropped as a serious development project and that core bugs will not be fixed.  It appears to be used as a template for experimentation instead.  That's cool but It would be nice to be able to actually play it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I honestly want to recommend this game, but I just can't.

Environments become a bit bland after a few minutes, and often fail to load.
If you even think about using a jetpack or hang glider for any distance you're doomed, as every time I used them I ended up clipping through the ground and getting trapped below the world.
Animations are awkward and combat is just boring.

Now I will admit that the crafting system is fun, being able to dig tunnels and build bases, but the building system is so complecated that by the time you've mastered it you will probably be out of creative energy and just want to play something else.

Basically, if they would clean up the animations, simplify the menu's and building system, and put some serious time into fixing their landscapes, this could be a really fun game, but it is seriously shackled by these shortcomings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't know about the other reviews, the game is being very actively developed, just check the log.  There is a new beta release about monthly.   It's also Early access, bugs are to be expected and then you give feedback.  I see so many early access reviews complaining about bugs.

Pretty awesome game and it's still in early access.  I also got Grav around the same time and both games are fun but each is different in big ways.  I had debated on which one to get for a while but in the end I got both thanks to my brother and his generosity.

Both game are beautiful with  bright and varied environments.  This will not be a review of Grav, I'll just briefly touch on some of the main differences.

Planet Explorers Story mode is the single player mode.  It has NPCs, missions and a story line.  I've only been playing Grav solo because the free weekend seems to have brought some griefers into the multiplayer servers and I wasn't about to deal with that, so I can't speak too much to the public multiplay, though I did set up a server for a friend and me to play.  Grav's single player is more just about exploration, but there are some tasks that you get some rewards for.

The story in Planet Explorers is pretty in depth so far.  You'll meet a lot of NPCs, with a lot of missions and rewards.  The biggest difference is with the crafting systems.  Planet Explorers is insanely cool when it comes to this.  In Grav you're working with about 10 resources that you'll need to craft pre-designed items, such as a jetpack or monocycle.  You'll have different workbenches for creating different items.  Planet Explorers has a lot more resources for creating things.  And then you'll create a few things to create bigger things, and then there is a custom editor built into the game for designing weapons, cars, planes, etc...There is no pre-made car, you have to build the wheels, cockpit, engine, fuel cell and then build it and export it into your world.  For example when I had to build a car for a mission, I needed wood and rubber for the wheels, steel, iron and motherboard for the enginer, and to make that motherboard I needed plastic and copper wiring.  This may sound tedious, but it isn't because you can click on a component in the crafting window and it will then open that component so you can click on the ingredients and make them and traverse the heirarchy that way.  It's VERY easy to quickly make components and see which components will create which parts.  You then go into the ISO editor (the name for a custom creation is ISO), which is like a modeler if you're familiar with 3D Modeling.  You'll place the 4 wheels, cockpit, engine, fuelcell and then build your car however you want.  If you google Planet Explorer ISOs you'll find websites devoted to models that you can download and play with.  There are turrets and lots of guns, it's amazing what people have done with this.

Grav has been fun so far, it's a different game.. and Planet Explorers is amazing and fun too.

TL;DR: Planet Explorers is amazing because you can create a lot of custom content very easily using many parts and resources.  The story mode is very indepth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game 6 months ago (pre-steam) thinking it would be an amazing upgrade from minecraft. Graphically it is, but when you get down to it. The controls are so bad. I don't know why a traditional WASD control system couldn't be used. It makes combat agains basic monsters so difficult expect to die after any encoutner

The custom design feature is pretty cool with one exception, there in no comprehensible tutorial included in the game. You basically have to know how to use auto-cat programs already or find a youtuber that explains the process well enough.

While Minecraft resource gathering is tideous, but in this game you literally have no way of knowing if you are gathering the right plant until seeing it for the 20th time and i hope you find it again. Wanna dig a giant hole in the ground? COOL! Just make sure you have a way out, because the caves in this game give you no hope for survival.

If you are trying to build a fort to protect from a monster onslaught good luck because those guys can pretty much fly. If a herd wants you dead, your chance of escape is like 20% tops.

Overall this game tries to take a game like Minecraft and add elements of modern gaming, however it lacks in the simplicity that minecraft was able to hand out on a silver platter, and it was done with no instructions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had the game for a pretty long time. I don't play often anymore since they hardly ever update the project.
Overall its a fun game, probably one of the most important metrics for sure.

However there are a plethora of bugs (game is in alpha after all so a certain number is expected), game performance has been terrible since release in the adventure mode for the game. Story mode while not complete gives you acceptable performance. Probably mainly due to the fact that its a static world and not randomly generated.

May want to avoid the games forums (the official ones, not the steam ones) though they are kinda dead, and the few people who are there won't take any critique of their precious game. (thats fanboys for ya, right?)

Overall the game showed ALOT of promise when I bought it over a year ago. However since then development has slowed to a crawl (though they did release an update today I see) and it is starting to be outpaced both graphically and
innovation wise by newer EA titles like Empyrion: Galactic Survival, Ark: Survival Evolved (even though that one is more mmo) and several other EA survival titles.

So in my opinion, skip it for now till they finish intigrating unity 5, and hopefully start putting the pieces back together from the switch over to the new engine. Play one of the other survival games for now. I strongly recommend Empyrion if you want to be able to get off world and have a good quality first person mode.

Don't waste your money.
I bought this about a year ago, it showed a lot of promise.
Then there were no updates for a longtime. Excuse is port to unity5. It feels like they've gone completely backwards and are still porting what they had.
I'm not a fan in general of early access, and this one hasn't helped. I tried the demo, thought there was enough there to buy, and feel like the second I handed over my money development stopped.
New things they are adding I'm not a fan of. The skill system already looks like something that is going to ruin this game (just like 7DaystoDie). I don't understand why every game wants to try to do everything and do it badly. It's not enough to have arbitrary tiers, lets slap arbitrary skill requirements on them, oh and make you research the stuff as well. That is the sure sign of we've reached the point of we don't have anything left so let's turn it into a long boring grind so you don't realize what a lack of content there really is".
So many games right now with so much promise
date: especially of the "Futuristic Minecraft-type clone with better graphics" (which in and of itself is not a bad thing)  it would be nice to see 1 actually get finished."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please read the review to see why I don't recommend. The game seems pretty cool. It doesn't run amazing and it's got lots of small bugs all over the place, but that's understandable. The game has lots of potential, but it's just not quite there yet, especially at the given price.

Lots of things are a little unclear on how to be done. This would be okay but when there's a story mode with a small built-in tutorial you'd think it would teach you a little more. But it has a cool charm to it. That's one of the reasons I didn't put it away to wait until it's fully released.

I'd very much like to see this game get done, but it seems like it never will be. It's been in production for a long while, and even though many, many folks have purchased the early access it seems like things don't move so much quicker. That's important to releasing a good game. And the devs are always making small fixes and improvements, but it's been a long while since we've seen a big update.

I WANT to recommend this game, but I can't yet. It has lots of potential, but in its current state I can't recommend yet.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlanet explorers is the best open world sand box game that I have everr played. The combat is excellent with many different types of weapons to use and a wide variety of animals and aliens to hunt and all of them give some type of resource upon killing them, usually meat or some item that can be sold to vendors for currency. The crafting system is excellent and has many armor pieces that can be crafted out of differnt level resources from wood to diamonds. The crafting system also allows you to design and build custom armor, weapons, and aircraft/vehicles/boats all with their own individual stats based on what material you used and how much of that material is in the design. You can also manage a colony and build many useful buildings in the colony such as replicator, training station, repair facilities and more. You can build a tram in the game world and then ride in that tram. There are many quests to do in the story mode. There is a good farming system once you have a colony set up. There is a lot of things to do in this game. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most Potential for an Alpha

(written 4/4/2014)

Althought this game currently in alpha it already shows a lot of potential for the future. At the moment however their are many different surface level issues with the game. For example the textures seem somewhat bland, the animations for the characters while correct for the movements involved are a bit offputting and somewhat unnatural, difficult camera controls and the currency for multiplayer is way to easy to obtain. However I suspect that these problems will fizz away, not unlike a can of soda after being poured into a glass.

This games gameplay is fantastic. Creating unique weapons and vehicles puts this a teir above any competition that does not feature said mechanics. The building is smooth and is easy to master. Combat could be better though, using swords has a bit of an mmo feel to it. The online multiplayer works great too. I love the environments and unique creatures featured in the game, even if some of them don't seem to match up from time to time. Overall, It's a ton of fun, and the concept of this game is what I hoped the next generation of sandbox survival builders to be like. However, I'd like to see improvements.

i highly recomend this game so much fun, even tho its still in early alpha. there are a few major bugs e.g dont alt tab or the game will crash without saveing but the game auto saves alot so you shouldnt lose much. if its your 1st time playing go with the story mode it will teach you slowly rather then throwing you into the game that will be too much and make you hate the game,

theres a customaztion part of the game where you can completly make weapons and vehicals in a voxal basid way, rather annoying to learn how to use but its so cool. there are cars/anything you can think of that can move on wheels theres aircraft jets/helicopters/anything you can think of any design and theres battleships to be made you can easyly spend 5 hours makeing a gun look awesome or just make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one that works will how you need it to,

its a open ended game although im not sure if theres an ending for the story once you have done all the quests. theres a sweet base making system and you can make your base anyway that you can think of. there is multiplayer although the developers are focusing on singleplayer for the most part.

a must buy game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most Potential for an Alpha

(written 4/4/2014)

Althought this game currently in alpha it already shows a lot of potential for the future. At the moment however their are many different surface level issues with the game. For example the textures seem somewhat bland, the animations for the characters while correct for the movements involved are a bit offputting and somewhat unnatural, difficult camera controls and the currency for multiplayer is way to easy to obtain. However I suspect that these problems will fizz away, not unlike a can of soda after being poured into a glass.

This games gameplay is fantastic. Creating unique weapons and vehicles puts this a teir above any competition that does not feature said mechanics. The building is smooth and is easy to master. Combat could be better though, using swords has a bit of an mmo feel to it. The online multiplayer works great too. I love the environments and unique creatures featured in the game, even if some of them don't seem to match up from time to time. Overall, It's a ton of fun, and the concept of this game is what I hoped the next generation of sandbox survival builders to be like. However, I'd like to see improvements.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is really amazing, the depth is there but you are not required to get into it.  As fun as any survival game but without the repetitive zombie theme, instead you get a nice change with the sci-fi theme that brings crazy scenery, plants, bugs and even a somewhat scary enemy.  jEven at the early stage of alpha this game is currently in there is so much to do, once you figure out how to do something you will quickly be finding more and more to do and before you know it you have played for 6 hours.  You might think you would have gotten alot done in that time, well not likely the map in this game.....its enormous.  But for good reason, there is a creation system in the game that allows you to create; like actually create" your own vehicles.  You get the basic guts and mechanical stuff

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an alpha, this game is surprisingly finished. It shows some serious promise and already is fun as is... well, minus the bugs and the choppy combat systems. The tutorials are a tad confusing, but nothing you can't learn on your own. With more content and maybe a more stable system of controls and combat, this game will be near everything I hoped it would be.

On a side note: the rpg aspect/adventure aspect create a strong MMO feel. . . like it or leave it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is kinda confusing at the very beginning but all you have to remember is F2 locks and unlocks your cursor and you can harvest alot of the things in the game.  Mining goes below ground with what limit I have yet to try to reach.  The crafting in the game is simple enough and can be done anywhere and you can make multiples at one time in the same time as one which takes alot of the repetativeness of crafting in other games out.  There are a few flaws that I don't like such as the chat popping up when someone talks in a Multiplayer game but if you just move the window out of your way instead of closing it everytime it won't do it anymore.

This review is short for the fact that the game is still in Alpha and I have only played 5 hours so far but this game is definately going in the right track.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love the opportunity and the diversity of the game. Sure, it has a lot of glitches and bugs but thats what you get for playing an alpha game. Every person that buys this game contributes to making this game a better game. One upsides would be that you have a great deal of freedom in how you tackle the game, especially the crafting/ISO portion gives way for really fun creations. On the down side, it's kinda slow going and a bit daunting sometimes. Plus combat is kinda wonky at times and your weapons don't get real good until much much much later in the game. But overall it's a pretty wonderful and beautiful game that I enjoy playing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHaving problems chopping down trees and getting flowers? It's right click. Yup. Yarp's guide was to subtle for me and it took me a total of 20 minutes to figure how to chop down a tree so I'm gonna tell you all. RIGHT CLICK. Anyway, the trailer is good, but this game is pretty rough. It's not worth the 25$, more like 10. I'd wait a lot longer as its a really new game. Not even the character customization is completed yet! The way to save a world needs to be turned into a user friendly menu. The build mode is annoying, I think that should be removed and put the building into normal gameplay, not a mode. The ISO maker, which allows you to create your own items is amazing. But the waypoint thing for the map is glitchy, it doesn't put the waypoint where your mouse is. I'd say I'd recommend it, but only if you are going to wait a year, mostly because major updates are months apart.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers - If you build it you can play with it.

I love this game, with over 150 hours in it and so much to do.  I will say Planet Explorers is a missleading name.  At a glance it would seem you just hop from planet to planet and explore them, but there is only one planet.  Of course you can have a different planet each play through but you can't jump from one planet to the next.  What I mean by this is in adventure mode you can generate the type of planet you will explore, A mix of desert, trees, water, grassland etc...

You can make your own weapons - riffles, pistols (lasser or bullets).  When I say make you can use a preset weapon to craft, or you can build your own and play with it in the game.  Never played a game with such a nifty option.  It's really awesome to spend an hour designing your weapon, then build it in your adventure/story game.

You can make your own transportation - (note only on the planet can not leave the atmosphere and go into outerspace).  Make a 16 wheeler, make a mortorcycle, a 3 wheeler a 4 wheeler,  a tank, a pickup truck, a helicopter, a fighter jet, a flying carpet (lol someone actually did this).  Tons of things to create to drive and fly around in.  Once again its what ever you decide to create.

My advice to the developers of this game.  Change your main screen shot advertising this game to reflect more of what this game is about.  A guy and gal in a dust storm in cartoonish fashion doesn't set this up for how great this game is.
Maybe a screen shot with helicopters, Guns, mortorcycles, Jets.  If you build it they will come".

Great job on what is in the game so far
date: and can't wait for the AI update.  I just wish you would advertise or hype this game better for what it really is.  It's misleading in a bad way as it doesn't represent the true cool and fun factor."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've bought and played many a sandbox game, this one is by far my favorite.  Crafting, check, world modding, check, the ability to craft as many varied vehicles, weapons, tools etc, check!  The amount of hours ive played isnt showing up because i was unplugged for a month, i must have clocked in over 200hrs to date on this, and its still in alpha phase!!!  I've never regretted buying alpha, but with Planet Explorers, it already feels like a complete game, and just keeps getting better!  Kudos to the creators of PE! es, its an ambitious project, but so far its all been well implemented.  I highly recommend this game to fans of Minecraft/sandbox type games, and just buy the game already, build a VTOL, motorcycle etc, and tinker away!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game for some time, and I'm very excited it's made it to Early Access on Steam.  For a small indie game, the ambition this team has is immense.  The sheer scope of what they are creating is really amazing.  What's more, they are actually delivering.

Pros:  Huge world which is fully changeable by digging, shaping and building.  Amazingly-detailed item builder so you can build your own custom swords, shields, even vehicles!  The designs can be exported to .iso files so they can be shared too!  I hope this shows up in the workshop on Steam.

The graphics and sound are nice and character animations are believable.  Gameplay is wide-open with a lot of different ways to enjoy the game.  Single player story mode, Co-Op and competitive multiplayer are all options.  Time will tell if they all pan out.

There is a character designer with lots of options.  Hopefully more will surface as the game comes closer to release.

I think this game will be an amazing journey with lots of things to do.  I look forward to the finished product.

Cons:

Some of these items are due to the game not being finished yet, so they are subject to change.  The voice acting is very amateurish.  Not a big issue overall but there it is.  Combat needs some serious polish.  I feel like I'm switing a weapon, but no feedback when I hit doesn't make it feel like I'm hitting anything or being hit.  There are virtually no combat sounds either.  Combat is probably going to be a decent part of this game, so some polish to make it more satisfying would be nice.
